PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
Graduated family allowances are of important assistance to families with more than one child.
All family allowances, whether for one, two, three, or more children, have not kept pace with inflation.
There are suggestions that all family allowances should be paid at the one flat rate. This would severely disadvantage families with more than one child.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should reject any suggestion that family allowances be paid at a flat rate and instead should ask the Federal Government to increase the value of existing payments.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth: We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
That the anomalous Fringe Benefits Tax is iniquitous, inequitable and unfair on the grounds that-
it adversely affects business throughout Australia, including farms
by creating a further tax burden it destroys incentive
it has caused unemployment
it is costly to administer and its complexities have caused confusion and widespread anger.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of Labor's Fringe Benefits Tax legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Anzac Rifle Range, Malabar, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
1. That over 67,000 men, women and students enjoy the pursuit of their sport and recreation every year at the Anzac Rifle Range at Malabar and have done so since 1967.

2. The people of Sydney through their membership of 41 clubs headquartered at the Anzac Rifle Range together with a number of other community, school and commercial groups, the police and armed forces will lose this community facility if the Federal Government proceeds to sell the Range to private developers.
3. The Australian Bicentenary Fullbore Rifle Championships are to be conducted at the Anzac Rifle Range in April 1988 as part of the celebration of Australia's Bicentenary.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should ask the Federal Government to retain the Anzac Rifle Range for the continued use and enjoyment of the people of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Military and Intelligence Facilities in Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

1. The Watsonia Army Barracks contains electronic communication facilities, operated by Australian and American personnel, that give the United States the ability to pin-point Soviet nuclear submarines, hidden in the Oceans.

2. This would make it possible for U.S. killer-submarines to destroy all Soviet nuclear submarines, while the U.S. nuclear submarines launch their missiles in a `first-strike' attack. This makes Watsonia a potential nuclear target. A nuclear attack on Watsonia would have a disastrous effect on Melbourne.
3. The `joint U.S.-Australian' bases in Australia endanger rather than protect us. They also add a new menace to the nuclear arms race, that must be stopped.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should close the `Joint Australia-U.S.' Electronic Communication Facilities in the Watsonia Army Barracks.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation Schemes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
That many Australian wage and salary earners and self-employed persons do not enjoy secure retirement incomes provided by superannuation; and

That the Government issued in December 1985 Guidelines for the implementation of the proposed productivity decision by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and draft Operational Standards for Superannuation schemes.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government:
1. Guarantees to every employee the right and freedom to select the superannuation scheme of his/her choice.
2. Protects the individual exercising that freedom of choice from any coercion, influence or other pressure which may be applied by any employer, association or trade union.
3. Will recognise only those schemes which provide genuine superannuation and reject those schemes which do not provide for-
preservation of benefits to retirement
vesting of employer contributions
equal employer and employee Trusteeship control to ensure security of investments.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
That the Assets Test contains many anomalies, discriminates against people living in rural areas, and against veterans, and discourages people from accumulating assets for their retirement.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of the Labor Government's iniquitous and unfair Assets Test.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Has he yet found out, as he said he would last Thursday, who will be invited to make submissions to the review of the fringe benefits tax? Does he have any more detail on how the review is to be conducted and, in particular, what are the terms of reference of the review? I further ask: Will the review be broad enough to encompass the sort of change suggested by the chairman of the Government's rural task force, Mr Cunningham, namely that employers lose the right to deductions for benefits provided to employees and that this income be subject to normal company tax?

—As I have said on previous occasions, the review is being set up and will take place. When it has completed its deliberations, there will be an announcement that will provide comfort or otherwise to Senator Chaney and to other people who are concerned. I am not in a position to say precisely who will be invited, if that is the specific question directed to me. I am not in the position to say precisely what the terms of reference, so-called, are except that it is a review of the administrative arrangements relating to the tax. I forget the exact form of art that will be particularly concerned in relation to what are described as unintended consequences. So when those things are attended to there will be a result and Senator Chaney will have it.

—I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister to direct his mind to the fact that after the inquiry is concluded it will be of no use to anyone to know what the terms of reference are and who may make submissions. I ask him: When will the Government be in a position to say who will be invited to make submissions, when will the Government be in a position to say what the terms of reference are and when will the Government be in a position to respond to the many detailed inquiries that people have to make about this matter?

—I think the honourable senator ought to be clear about the fact that it is not, as I said in answering the first part of the question, a review of the philosophic assumptions underlying the tax or anything of that kind; it is a review of the administrative arrangements associated with that tax-
—What about anomalies? What is the intention?

—The terms of reference are not helped by interjections. I think that to try to elevate it and describe it as an inquiry, which involves the specific terms of reference going to philosophical assumptions and other things, is to over-exaggerate what it is all about. As I say, it is a review of administrative arrangements.
—What does that mean?
—It means just what I said, Senator. If the honourable senator is too thick to understand, that is his problem, not mine.
—Order!
—What about unintended consequences?
—Order! Senator Button is answering a supplementary question of the Leader of the Opposition.
—I have nothing further to add to what I said previously.

—Has the Minister for Education seen Press reports which claim that some university students in Queensland are being forced to sleep in cars or to give up study because they cannot afford the cost of higher education? Those Press reports said that Queensland students under the tertiary education assistance scheme were having difficulty coping and that the Federal Government's new administrative charge of $250 is likely to force more students to give up their studies. Does the Minister agree with those comments? Has the Government made any moves to ensure that students will not be prevented from entering, or discouraged from continuing, higher education courses because of that charge?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Reports of higher education issues in Queensland are usually put in fairly bizarre terms, and I think this is another example of that. I am not aware of any students having to sleep in cars because of the cost of higher education. Indeed the cost of higher education in Queensland, as in the rest of Australia, is absolutely minimal. The cost of higher education is the fee which institutions themselves levy on students, usually in the vicinity of $100, and from next year some students will be required to pay a Commonwealth-imposed administration charge of $250. But at the same time those who read reports such as this must bear in mind that students eligible for tertiary assistance have received substantial increases from the Hawke Labor Government. For example, this year under the Austudy arrangements, students aged 18 and above living at home will receive $45 a week next year compared with $35 a week this year, and that will go up to $55 a week in 1988. Independent students received $73 a week in 1986. This will increase to $80 next year and $95 in the following year. So it is quite clear that students from poorer families, that is those who are eligible for TEAS, have received and will receive substantial increases from our Government.

ANSWER.PARA: In the light of that I think it is very inaccurate for newspapers to report such cases of poverty as if they were the general circumstances of students. It is not to say that some students do not get themselves into very difficult circumstances, and it is not to say that there are not individual students who are having a very difficult time. But as far as the Government's res-sponsibility is concerned-that is, to provide allowances to assist students from poorer families-we have more than met that responsibility. It ought to be pointed out too that higher education students have many opportunities throughout the year to add to any allowances they may get by part time and casual work, and indeed most students do that. That has always been the tradition of higher education students in this country.

I think it is strange, if I might say so, that we are now getting criticisms of the administration charge by Liberal Party and National Party supporters and we are getting stories about the plight of students, when it is in fact the policy of the Liberal Party to impose full cost fees, that is thousands and thousands of dollars per year, and in the unlikely event of the Liberal-National Party being elected to government federally, we would have students sleeping in cars because they could not afford to pay $10,000 or $12,000 a year for a course. But under the present circumstances, where very minimal enrolment costs are involved for students, where student allowances have been increased quite considerably and where the opportunities for part time and casual work have increased under the successful policies of our Government, I think such stories are grossly exaggerated.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs to the breakdown of the Iceland summit between President Reagan and General Secretary Gorbachev. What could have been the most significant step towards nuclear disarmament appears to have foundered on the American Star Wars program. Will the Minister state, first, whether he believes that the steps towards disarmament in Iceland might be salvaged, and secondly, whether United States allies might put pressure on the Americans to think again about the value of the strategic defence initiative?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is looking forward to a detailed briefing on the Reykjavik meeting when Mr Kenneth Adelman, the Director of the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, visits Canberra tomorrow. It may well be appropriate after that briefing for the Foreign Minister to make a more detailed statement on this matter, perhaps addressing in more detail the particular question about the strategic defence initiative that Senator Foreman mentioned. For the moment, what I can say on behalf of the Foreign Minister and the Government is this: The meeting between President Reagan and General Secretary Gorbachev in Reykjavik on 11 and 12 October appears to have come close to unexpected agreements on quite dramatic reductions in intermediate range nuclear weapons and strategic nuclear arsenals. There also appears to have been progress on the issue of nuclear test bans, an area of very great importance to Australia and one on which we have been maintaining a very high international profile.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia welcomes this progress, but is, however, very deeply disappointed that disagreement over strategic defences, which are being developed by both sides, prevented such agreements being finalised. The Government does not endorse programs by either side which aim at the introduction of nationwide strategic defences against ballistic missiles. The view of the Government on SDI in particular has been expressed on numerous previous occasions. In the Government's view it is imperative that the United States and the Soviet Union do not, when great advances are so close, walk away from the process of dialogue, and that both sides build upon the progress made at Reykjavik. In this regard the Government is encouraged that both sides seem to recognise the importance of continuing to work together toward early agreements on reducing and eliminating nuclear arms. We recall that in preparations for the Iceland meeting it had not been planned as the forum for a final agreement and had been seen by both sides as essentially preparatory to a full summit meeting in Washington. With so much progress made, it is most important that the dialogue continue and that the Washington summit proceed. Finally, we note that useful discussions did reportedly take place on the other agenda items covering human rights, bilateral relations and regional conflicts. One would, of course, hope that those matters could also be progressed to formal agreement and not be left in the limbo that they appear to be in at the moment following the breakdown of the Reykjavik talks.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. Now that the Australian Council of Trade Unions is adding some pseudo-respectability to the hysterical chorus of the Right demanding that unemployed people be made to work for the dole, does the Minister agree that it is high time that the Government rejected the sleazy and simplistic hound-the-victim campaign of the Right, whether new or old, and addressed the question of actually providing constructive opportunities for work or education? In particular, has the Government given any consideration to encouraging local government to develop local employment initiatives? Finally, would it now consider, despite the intended deferral of the poverty traps legislation, substantially increasing the permissible income level-at least for unemployed people-to provide an incentive for parttime work or to start an enterprise, as recommended by former Senator Chipp as early as February 1985?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a bit taken aback. I am not used to such emotive language in this place. It is very hard for me to take. My understanding of the ACTU's proposal is that the Government and industry will provide opportunities for unemployed people to work or undergo training, and where that work or training is available unemployed people, particularly young unemployed people, should be obliged to take part in that work or training if they wish to receive unemployment benefit. We already have a work test arrangement under which young or old unemployed people are obliged to seek work if it is available. In that regard the ACTU proposal is not so different from what now exists. Secondly, I would like Senator Powell to look outside the boundaries of this country sometime; she will find that that is what happens in all social democracies in Western Europe and in comparable countries elsewhere.

ANSWER.PARA: What this Party, this Government and many members of this Parliament have been concerned about in the past have been proposals which would force young people who are unemployed to work under less than award conditions and to work for people who wished to exploit them by getting cheap labour. I understand that that is not the ACTU's proposal. Nor is it the proposal of most people who advocate this sort of program. To describe such a proposal as sleazy and in the emotive terms that Senator Powell used may well get her onto the front page of the newspapers tomorrow but it will not do a thing for unemployed people in this community. Unemployed people need the opportunity to work and get training to improve their capacity to work. All the expressions of the type that Senator Powell has come out with today will not help them.

I remember Senator Chipp's proposal in this place about getting local government to provide work and opportunities for work for young unemployed people. That proposal did not have any opposition from this side of the House or from the other side of the House. It was a proposal to ensure that young people had the opportunity to fulfil their capacities in this society. I see nothing wrong with that, nor do I see anything wrong with what I have read of the ACTU's proposal. I will look at the rest of the words that Senator Powell used today to see whether there are any questions that I have not answered. I will attempt to answer them later in detail.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: WAR WIDOW'S PENSION: MRS ELMA DOYLE

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to my question of 7 October regarding $20,000 in back pay of a repatriation pension owed to a war widow, Mrs Elma Doyle of Sydney. The Minister will be aware of references in Press reports on this matter to Mr Peter Thompson of Pension Advisory Services, who supposedly is acting on Mrs Doyle's behalf. Does the Minister know whether Mr Thompson is charging Mrs Doyle a fee for his services? If so, is she getting value for money?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall Senator Zakharov raising the question of the back payment to Mrs Doyle which had been stalled as a result of some weaknesses in the legislation. I reiterate what I said on that occasion: The Government has to have a legislative basis for the payment of taxpayers' funds to recipients. Unfortunately, there has been a defect in the legislation which will be rectified as a result of legislation introduced in the House of Representatives.

ANSWER.PARA: A Mr Peter Thompson of Pension Advisory Services is claiming to represent Mrs Doyle in this matter. Unfortunately, Pension Advisory Services is not a voluntary organisation. It is a pity that Mrs Doyle has been caught up in the arrangements that gentleman is making on her behalf when veterans organisations, in particular the Returned Services League and Legacy, could quite conceivably have made representations on her behalf, as her local member has made to me, for an expedition of this matter.

I have learnt that Mr Thompson charges his clients 10 per cent of any entitlement they will eventually obtain. If that information is correct, it means that Mrs Doyle will pay Mr Thompson something like $2,000 in regard to a matter which could have been represented voluntarily by veterans organisations. There is no need for any veteran to go to any advisory agency for the purpose of representing his or her view to the Government, whichever government is in power. Such matters can be properly dealt with by the Department or, if that is not sufficient, through the voluntary organisations such as, in this case, the RSL, Legacy or, for that matter, any other ex-service organisation. Certainly such matters can be and have been adequately represented to me by the local member of parliament.

I warn veterans, and war widows in particular, to avoid any of these self-appointed organisations which appear from time to time seeking to exploit the circumstances in which people find themselves and rake off public funds which are normally available to the beneficiaries.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to reports in this morning's Sydney Daily Telegraph of a statement by a spokesman for the National Roads and Motorists Association in New South Wales which blames bad roads rather than bad drivers for Australia's road toll? If so, can the Minister say whether there is any basis for this assertion?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have seen the article by the NRMA, which represents the drivers in this country. It is a pity that that organisation has sought to apportion the total blame for the high road accident rate in this country to the state of the roads. Whilst the Government accepts that that is a factor, it is not the Government's view-nor is it the view of those associated with road safety-that that is the sole factor for the high incidence of accidents and deaths in respect of our roads. The Federal Government has some responsibilities in these matters and it has taken a number of initiatives. In consultation with the States it has introduced graduated licences. It has drawn attention to the problems of alcohol with respect to driving. It has carried out an education program and, in fact, has produced a video called Road Worrier for use in schools for the purpose of educating future drivers on the need for care and safety when driving on the roads. It has also carried out a very extensive policy of spending money on improving our road systems.

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised that the Department of Transport is of the view that some Australians are appalling drivers. They are regarded as being arrogant, aggressive, impatient and inconsiderate in respect of their relationship with other drivers. Therefore, those attitudes also have to be taken into consideration if we are to solve this problem of the high accident rate on Australia's roads. It is the Government's view, which I think is also a view shared by the States, that it is not just a question of spending more money. I would have thought that the NRMA would have taken greater responsibility for improving road manners rather than just suggesting that we spend willy nilly billions more money on road construction in Australia and that this expenditure would somehow reduce the road toll. There are a number of factors which have to be taken into consideration. The Commonwealth believes that it is carrying out its responsibility but it would expect the NRMA to play a much more positive role in realising the objective of reducing the road toll in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. The Minister would be aware that members of the Labor Caucus have identified what they see as anomalies in the fringe benefits tax. Does the Minister agree that the following examples put forward by Mr Ronald Edwards, a member of the House of Representatives, represent anomalies: Ruling No. MT2025 which requires cray boat owners to pay fringe benefits tax on the value of accommodation provided at sea; a discount allowed for car lots provided for live-in mortuary workers but refused for car yard caretakers; and the payment of fringe benefits tax on safety awards given to workers in the Western Australian timber industry? Or does the Minister believe that the tax is being properly applied in these instances?

—I said in a television interview last Friday-I think this part of the interview was telecast on Sunday-that there is an element of subjectivity in what is and what is not an anomaly. I accept that the facts are as Senator Crichton-Browne has stated they are; that is, that Mr Edwards has drawn attention to those specific examples and that Mr Edwards is correct in his statements about those particular examples. I am not going to get involved in a discussion here about whether they or any other alleged anomalies are in fact anomalies. But within a couple of weeks the Government should have made a decision to determine the facts as to the application of the tax and judgments about what anomalies, if any, are there.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce been drawn to a statement released yesterday by the National Farmers Federation claiming that the Government's decision to cease paying the consumption subsidy on imported fertilisers would increase the price of fertilisers to some farmers? If so, what was the basis of the Government's decision to cease paying the subsidy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I did see the statement. I have had a meeting with the National Farmers Federation about this matter. I am aware of the statement which was made and certainly aware of the views expressed in the statement. The National Farmers Federation is perhaps not as certain of its position as the Press release might have indicated. The National Farmers Federation was consulted extensively during the Government consideration of this matter and on a number of occasions expressed support for the removal of consumption subsidies from imported fertilisers; that is to say, at least sections of the National Farmers Federation did. So there are, I think, conflicting views amongst farmers about this issue. Of course there are conflicting impacts of any decision in relation to the fertiliser industry because of geographical factors of distance, the spread of use of different types of fertilisers throughout Australia and so on.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government regards the decision in the Budget to cease the subsidisation of imported fertilisers as being very logical. It would be difficult in Australia at present to argue the validity of subsidising imports. This does not seem to make sense to us. The total amount of the subsidy removed from imported fertilisers, some $13m per annum, has been redirected to farmers through an increase in the subsidy on locally produced fertilisers, for which the total allocation is $55m per annum. Following that decision there was a reduction in the price of fertilisers produced in Australia by at least two of the three major manufacturers-Pivot Fertilizers in Victoria and Ingitec in Queensland. The decisions to reduce prices were made consequent upon the Government's decision.

We will shortly announce a strengthening of the monitoring arrangements which have been in place for many years directed to ensuring that the full subsidy continues to be passed on to the rural sector. That is an important part of the decision. The Government believes that the decision will have a three-pronged effect on the fertiliser market in Australia. Firstly, as I have said, since the announcement of the decision local fertiliser prices have dropped and in one case a price rise announced just before the Budget has been withdrawn. Secondly, all duties have been or are to be removed from imported fertilisers so that they will be available to farmers at world prices. I refer essentially to the 2 per cent duty which was imposed by the Fraser Government. It has been withdrawn in respect of imported fertilisers. Thirdly, it will result in the strengthening of the Australian fertiliser manufacturing industry. That industry has extensive plans to restructure and is investigating new investments which will make it better able to supply the needs of the Australian agricultural sector.

I think it is important to remember in this context of consideration of the Australian fertiliser industry that it is a negatively assisted industry. Of course there is a conflict between the immediate requirements of the rural sector and medium to long term plans for an industry such as that. Nobody in this Parliament would be thanked if in five years time we did not have a fertiliser industry. I think that factor must be taken into account.

The process of rationalising the industry is already under way. For example, in Perth, Wesfarmers has now increased its holdings in both CSBP and Farmers Ltd and Kwinana Nitrogen Co. Pty Ltd to 100 per cent. Wesfarmers is a farmers' co-operative. It is owned by representatives of the rural sector. Two of the four major producers in Australia are farmers' co-operatives. They are owned by rural producers. I think it is important to say that the possibility of local manufacturers and importers exploiting farmers in Western Australia, as the National Farmers Federation's statement of yesterday suggested, is rather unlikely, if that co-operative is doing its job properly on behalf of the interests of its owners as well as its consumers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. What basis was there for the Minister's attempt during his Sunday program interview to make the Australian Taxation Office and the Commissioner of Taxation scapegoats for the Government's bungling over the fringe benefits tax? What specifically was he referring to when he said that some rulings issued on the tax had applied the tax in areas where `some people in government did not expect it would be'?

—If Senator Collard wants answers to questions like that, he had better get himself a job as a television interviewer instead of a politician, because I certainly do not intend to share with him what I thought about some of those specific incidents. The main thrust of his question-insofar as it had any thrust-is that I attempted to rubbish the Taxation Office. That was a headline which appeared in a couple of papers. It is not, in my view, an accurate interpretation of what I said. I make the point, using similar words to those which I used on the Sunday program, that when any taxation law is introduced, there is always some scope for interpretation in the application, in specific circumstances, of the letter of the law, since an Act, of course, cannot have written into it every conceivable circumstance under which it may be applied.
—Explain it to them. They wouldn't know. There were no tax cuts in seven years.

—There were no tax cuts in the seven years during which the Opposition was in government; that is so. The necessity for interpretation is there-usually by way of Commissioner rulings. It is far from clear, even to people who have considerable expertise in the drafting or interpretation of taxation law, precisely what is the way in which the law should be interpreted in every circumstance. We have, in demonstration of that, the fact that various commissioners have made judgments about taxation assessments which have gone to Taxation Boards of Review, Supreme Courts, the High Court and so on. I cite as a specific example-and one which is by no means obscure-that it took many years before the question of whether expenses incurred in travelling to and from work by people was to be permitted as a taxation deduction. That was finally resolved in the High Court after many contests in lower courts, appeal tribunals, and judgments and interpretations by the Commissioner. There is nothing new about that.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer to the article by Katharine West in the Weekend Australian headed: `Offsets club supervises a tragic economic waste'. The article alleges that the Government has not made the offsets program work to major effect in promoting potential growth areas in the economy; that government bureaucrats have entered into cosy deals with pet foreign companies rather than fight for a changed system that would work better for Australia in the longer term; and that there is a $1 billion backlog in the offsets program, which amounts to either an administrative scandal or a tragic economic waste. Has the Minister seen the article? If so, can he comment on whether these allegations are true.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The article was drawn to my attention. I read it because it was a refreshing departure for Ms Katharine West to be talking about a different issue from her normally recycled issues of families and fringe benefits. I am surprised that she took her pen to dealing with the offsets program, which seems to be very little related to her normal theme. The sad thing is that she got it wrong. Perhaps she should go back to the recycled article and keep on with that rather than deal with something about which she clearly does not have much information or has incorrect information.

ANSWER.PARA: The figure of $1.2 billion of outstanding offsets obligations was the figure which was about when we came to government. It was there for most of the period of the Fraser Government and, as Katharine West had some input into that Government's activities, perhaps she should have advised it about that matter at the time.

The fact of the matter is that the outstanding offset obligations are substantially less than that figure. There has been a very big impact on that backlog as a result of the changed offset policy which this Government introduced following an inquiry by Sir Brian Inglis and which we introduced from the beginning of this year. Since then the program has been subject to very rigorous public review and evaluation procedures. The article in question is cycled on information which is very out of date. I hope Katharine West's other information is more soundly based.

The most surprising thing of all about the article is that it did not refer at all to any of the major offsets agreements which the Government has signed in the last month or so and which will be worth approximately $360m to Australian industry. I just want to summarise some of those offset agreements which are significant. Only three weeks ago the Managing Director of Rolls-Royce came to Australia and announced that that company would set up a plant and equipment to produce titanium jet turbine engine blades, a plant which will be worth $15m and which will export $10m worth of product a year over the next six years. That visit by Rolls-Royce to Australia to establish that facility was made under the offsets program and the visit of the Managing Director to Australia was made as a return visit, as it were, for a visit made to Rolls-Royce in Britain by officers of my Department.

Later last month Airbus Industries announced that it was negotiating $130m worth of offsets and these included the production of aircraft parts for jet aircraft. In making that commitment the company said: `We recognise that the Australian Government wishes to bring new work and new technology into local industry and with that in mind we are discussing a number of other new projects'. Earlier this month General Electric Aircraft Engine Business Co. announced an offsets package worth $101m. In light of Ms West's criticisms we should note that General Electric's potential involvement does not involve just the production of parts for aircraft engines; it too is looking at the development of steam injected gas turbines, titanium forgings and the formation of a data bank for industry information which will help new ventures in Australia. The list goes on and on and involved $300m worth of commitments last month. So much for the assertion that the offsets system does not help develop potential growth areas in our economy. There are a number of other examples.

The other point which was made with characteristic yellow pages flair, if I might say so, was the suggestion of cosy deals `between bureaucrats and pet foreign companies'. Allegations of cosy deals have been made about the offsets program from time to time. No evidence has been produced to support any of those allegations under this Government or the previous Government when the allegations were similarly made.

I make the point that prior to the revision of the offsets arrangements introduced this year certain industries were much more likely to be beneficiaries of offsets arrangements than the much wider range of industries which are now beneficiaries of the arrangements as a result of changes which have been made. For example, in the aerospace industry there was always a number of firms which were the prime beneficiaries of previous offsets arrangements. At the present time, by contrast, large numbers of computer hardware firms are involved in offset arrangements with Australian industries and the degree of cosiness here or otherwise can be judged by recent Press articles about those arrangements with that industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like black hats and white hats.

—That is partly what I was referring to. Given the recent amount of publicity about civil offsets achievements, I am very surprised about the apparent lack of awareness of the program and the guidelines within which it operates. I hope that future articles in that column will be based a little more on research rather than ignorant assertion.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to his recent announcement regarding the establishment of an Australian space board in response to the report of the Space Science and Technology Working Party titled `A Space Policy for Australia'. I ask, firstly, whether the Minister agrees with the recent comments of the head of the inquiry, Sir Russel Madigan, who said:

QUESTION.PARA: The Government agreed with the recommendations but they've made sure they won't happen. A bureaucratic machine can't do it. We needed a hot-shot private enterprise-style organisation.
Secondly, does the Minister agree with his advisor on aerospace and technology matters that the Madigan report was `emotive and nationalistic'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The prime problem with the organisation of space industry related activities in Australia was one of co-ordination and development of concepts in various industries relevant to space technology. The essential function of the space board, which I announced following the Budget, is to try to bring together some of that fragmented activity in various industries and see it as being part of the contribution to a whole strategy in relation to space industry involvement. I will give the honourable senator an example. There are always overseas visitors coming here who want to talk about space industry related issues concerning remote sensing or rocketry and there has never been essentially a focal point for them to go to which embraces the diverse interests of Commonwealth and State governments or of various departments of the Commonwealth Government. The space board will have an important function as being a contact point and as a board which will try to co-ordinate those activities. The board was not allocated as much money as the Government would have liked had we been in a more favourable fiscal climate. We did not see as a possibility the priority of allocating a very large sum of money, as the Madigan report in fact recommended, in terms of space related activity.

ANSWER.PARA: I notice that Sir Russel Madigan has since said that we do not need a departmental body, we need a private enterprise body to handle these things. Be that as it may, there is no private enterprise body, or perhaps a set of individuals, with appropriate qualifications or even interests at this time to constitute such a body as a solely private sector activity. However, I do not recall the names of all of the members of the board, but I think out of five or six, four are from the private sector and one is from the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. It is not a body composed of bureaucrats in any sense as they are all essentially from the private sector of CSIRO, which has a very important research and development role in Australia's limited space activity.

I would also add that although to many Australians the concept of Australia being involved in space activity seems somewhat remote, if that is the appropriate expression to use about space, we are in fact significant users of space related technology through Aussat Pty Ltd, the Overseas Telecommunications Commission, Landsat and remote sensing facilities. A whole range of activities in the communications system in this country is very dependent of space technology of one kind or another. It is estimated that in the 1990s there will be a very large expenditure by governments in Australia particularly, and to some extent by private users, on space related equipment. Having said all that, there are a number of Australian companies which are showing that they can involve themselves in high technology aspects of space related engineering and other activities. For example, Kel Aerospace Pty Ltd has just been successful in obtaining a small but significant contract from the Canadian Government. Other Australian companies are involved in the building of ground stations, radio telescope equipment, and things of that kind. So I think there is some prospect, and I do not think Sir Russel Madigan or anyone else should take too gloomy a view of the prognosis.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Resources and Energy aware of an article in the Brisbane Telegraph on 13 October in which the Premier of Queensland has predicted that fuel prices will rise to more than 60c per litre by Christmas this year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the article reporting the assertions of the Premier in yesterday's Telegraph. I am able to tell Senator Jones that, as usual, the Premier's statement is full of blatant untruths and misrepresentations. There is simply no accuracy whatsoever in any statement that I see in that article. Let me catalogue some of the sins. In the first place, he says that petrol prices have risen by 16c per litre since the Hawke Government came to office. That is simply not true. The March quarter in 1983 saw the basic indicative retail price in Brisbane at 42.2c per litre; the equivalent figure in October 1986 is 51.9c. That is a rise of 9.7c per litre, not 16c. He is way out. In the second place the Premier says that the Federal Government has refused to pass on the drop in world oil prices earlier this year. That is simply not true. A very significant proportion of that drop was passed on. Although some of the prices have come back up with the rise in world oil prices, the reality is still that the wholesale price in Brisbane and elsewhere around the country is still 6 per cent lower in real terms than it was 12 months ago.

ANSWER.PARA: The claim is that there has been a massive negative effect on rural producers as a result of, again, the Government's alleged failure to pass on the drop in world oil prices. The Government went out of its way to make special concessions to ensure that rural producers, so far as their off-road use of diesel was concerned, got the full benefit of world oil price drops without any compensating increase in product excise. The reality has been that as a result of the Commonwealth's explicit concessions to rural producers, rural diesel prices for off-road use are still 40 per cent lower than for other consumers. That has been worth $364m to farmers in the period between March and October this year.

As to the claim about petrol prices increasing to 60c by the end of the year, that again is a wholly misleading and wholly inaccurate projection on any view of the likely reality. There are only three ways prices could increase: First, by an increase in world oil prices; secondly, by a major further depreciation of the Australian dollar; or thirdly, by some massive increase in State taxation. There is no likely prospect of any major or further depreciation of the Australian dollar, certainly not by that order of magnitude, between now and the end of the year. No economic commentator is suggesting anything of that kind.

So far as an increase in world oil prices generally is concerned, there would have to be an increase of the order of $A30 in the world oil price between now and the end of the year to cause the Brisbane price of 51.9c to rise to 60c. Even if one takes into account the maximum rural differential, which adds another possible maximum of 5.7c per litre to that Brisbane figure, there would still need to be an increase in world oil prices of about $A10 by the end of the year were we to get anywhere near 60c per litre. Nobody suggests, even on the most extraordinary reading of what is likely to come out of the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries meeting, that anything like that will happen with world oil prices. The only other way that prices could possibly increase by that amount would be if there were some State taxation slug. I am sure that the Premier would be only too enthusiastic about imposing such a slug if he had the chance but, for the sorts of reasons that I have been mentioning today, the blatant untruths of which this man constantly is guilty, I am sure that the electors of Queensland will have far too much sense to give him the chance to impose any such taxation increase.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 September Senator Vallentine asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Defence, whether I had heard of Vice-Admiral Henry C. Mustin and his article `Maritime Strategy from the Deckplates'. I had to confess to the Senate that I had not heard of either the Vice Admiral or his article. I have now, however, been briefed on the article by the Minister for Defence. Its contents only reinforce what I previously said to the Senate about the nature of the United States Navy's maritime strategy and the role of North West Cape. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the remainder of the detailed response to Senator Vallentine.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The response read as follows-
There has been no change in the US commitment to deterrence-its strategy remains defensive and is intended to deter Soviet use of force.
Admiral Mustin specifically acknowledges that the fundamental premise of the Maritime Strategy is deterrence, as indeed did Admiral Watkins.

In February I said that the Maritime Strategy, as we understand it, was a framework for considering all possible uses of maritime power in a broad range of strategic contingencies ranging from peace to war.

This is exactly what Admiral Mustin has done. In the context of the North Atlantic and NATO, he describes the relevance of the Maritime Strategy to deterrence, and goes on to consider its application should deterrence fail.
While there has been increasing US emphasis on forward deployment, as is evident from Admiral Mustin's article, these are changes in tactics, not strategies.
Forward deployment, however, has long been a part of US strategy. As the US Secretary for Defence, Mr Weinberger, said in his Annual Report to Congress in February 1986:
``Forward deployment has been a consistent and substantial component of our deterrent strategy for more than three decades''.

Forward deployment is described by Secretary Weinberger as a clear sign of the US commitment to the common defence of its allies. It enhances US capabilities to respond quickly with and on behalf of those allies.

Finally, and quite apart from the fact that nowhere in his article does Admiral Mustin refer to the Pacific Ocean-or for that matter the Indian Ocean-nothing he says changes the role of North West Cape. The naval communications station there continues to serve as a key element in a complex system of communications supporting the global balance.

DEBATE.TITLE: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE MINISTERIAL MEETING, URUGUAY ROUND

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the ministerial declaration on the Uruguay round of negotiations relating to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and seek leave to make a statement relating thereto and to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

Three weeks ago at Punta Del Este, Uruguay, I participated in a Gatt Ministerial meeting where agreement was reached to launch a new comprehensive round of multilateral trade negotiations. The launching of the ``Uruguay Round'' as it will be known, is a major victory for those of us seeking to reinforce a more liberal fair and open multilateral trading system.

We achieved what many thought was impossible-an international commitment to resist protectionism, to strengthen and improve existing trading rules, and to expand the multilateral trading rules to cover major areas currently not subject to Gatt disciplines.
There were two main achievements in this regard.
First, we started the process of establishing international rules for the so-called ``new areas''-principally trade in services.
Secondly, we provided a basis to bring effectively into the Gatt framework for the first time the longstanding issue of equitable treatment for agricultural trade.
A measure of this second achievement is that since the inception of the Gatt in 1948 there have been no less than nine failed attempts to bring agriculture under effective Gatt disciplines.

There were the seven post war mountain rounds, the 1954/55 review session at which the United States achieved a further erosion of agricultural trade rules by obtaining a waiver from the existing permissive rules and the disastrous 1982 Gatt ministerial.

In my statement on trade policy in this chamber on 20 February this year, I stressed the important opportunity provided by a new round of multilateral trade negotiations to focus attention on the current bias in the rules against agricultural trade.
The new round also provides Australia with an opportunity to create conditions for improved export performance in the fastest growing areas of world trade-manufactures and services.
The creation of such conditions is concomitant with the Government's industry and trade policy objectives-as is the need to reduce the structural distortions plaguing commodity markets.

I am pleased to report that we came away from the Punta Del Este ministerial meeting having achieved all of the objectives we identified for a satisfactory launching of negotiations. Multilateral trade negotiations will soon get under way on the full range of international trade problems confronting us.

Certainly the decision to launch a new trade round taken at Punta Del Este will not solve all our problems. The Agricultural subsidies war continues. Enormous stocks of agricultural commodities continue to overhang the world market. Protectionist pressures are still evident throughout the world, and the situation could deteriorate further before improving.

The importance of achieving the commencement of the ``Uruguay Round'' of mountain's lies in its unmistakeable signal of a change in direction. Peace talks have finally begun and the problems have been acknowledged. To this extent we can look to the future with a measure of confidence rather than despair.
But let there be no doubt about it-the negotiations will be tough. Changing a trading environment nurtured by forty years of distortion in the rules represents a formidable challenge.

Yet we are optimistic that these negotiations will produce multilateral agreement on new rules and disciplines that will open significant new opportunities for Australian exporters and strengthen the global trading system.
We seek a substantial move towards trading based on comparative advantage; an environment where Australian exporters can compete on fair terms.
The meeting in Uruguay followed seven months of preparatory discussions in Geneva.

Australia's strategy throughout that preparatory process was to co-operate fully with other like-minded countries to ensure that our views were heard and our aspirations taken into account. Particularly, we were determined that any new round should seriously tackle the growing crisis surrounding agricultural trade issues.
Agriculture still accounts for nearly 40 per cent of Australia's export revenue. Yet poor returns are threatening the wellbeing of our agricultural sector.

One major factor stands out above all others as the principal cause of declining agricultural commodity prices. It is the protection and production subsidies of Europe and the United States which have encouraged more production and investment than has been warranted-production creating surpluses which have then been placed on world markets with the aid of export subsidies.
Depressed prices for fair traders, such as Australia, have been the most discernible result. Similar policies have denied us legitimate access to other affluent markets such as Japan.

The critical need for Australia to address the problem is well documented. But there is an equal urgency for the European Community and the United States. Neither they, nor indeed the world, can afford to sustain the costs of rapidly escalating subsidy warfare.

The budget costs of all subsidies provided by European Community and the United States to their farmers is phenomenal-an estimated $US76 billion from their combined coffers in 1986, following on $US60 billion last year. The United States accounts for $US35 billion of that horrendous sum, Japan $US18 billion and the European Community $US23 billion.
But it doesn't end there.

If consumer transfers are added, the total cost of subsidies for the three majors approaches $US180 billion. Add taxation and the contributions of individual member states and the United States state governments, and the total climbs towards a staggering $US200 billion.

It is the impact of these sums that is forcing a growing international appreciation of the need to tackle the problems facing agriculture. Yet still, before Punta del Este, smaller trading nations acting alone were unable to bring these issues into a focus sharp enough to attract the attention of the major trading economies.

In the lead up to Punta del Este some of these smaller nations such as Australia, Uruguay, Argentina and Thailand worked long and hard, and indeed, effectively, to bring these issues to the negotiating table.
Our shared desire to build a ``Third Force'' on agricultural trade issues motivated our initiative for an agricultural fair traders ministerial meeting at Cairns in August.

In no small measure the success achieved on the negotiating mandate for Agriculture at Punta del Este can be attributed to the solidarity and vitality of the ``Cairns Group'' of fair trading nations. For the first time, smaller agricultural exporters as a group became an effective voice in the negotiations.
For the first time, the focus was too sharp to ignore.

The unity and resolve of the group surprised many. The pivotal role it played in the week-long process of intensive bargaining and negotiation surprised even more. Our rapid establishment as a third agricultural force allowed us to retain the initiative in the crucial eleventh hour deliberations with the majors.

As a result we achieved a negotiating mandate, a mandate which for the first time embraces all subsidies-direct and indirect including export subsidies. It has shifted the focus towards the root causes of the current agricultural crisis and the need to reduce and eliminate these negative distorting influences.
That mandate has been clearly recognised by the major protagonists in the current subsidy war.

The E.C.'s Commissioner de Clerc told the final plenary at Punta del Este that while the E.C.'s fundamental common policies and mechanism were not up for negotiation, `agriculture will be fairly and squarely addressed in the Uruguay round-in our own interest as well as in that of other contracting parties'. U.S. trade representative Yeutter, while conceding that it would be several years before the GATT negotiations themselves bore fruit, said that `in the interim, the United States will continue to pursue policies that enhance free and fair trade, including the aggressive enforcement of U.S. laws that address the problem of unfair trading practices by our trading partners'.
So the signs are all good, but we too will be expected to demonstrate our commitment to the negotiating process.
The reforms and benefits being sought in the negotiating round, if achieved, will not be costless. All participants will be required to accept some discipline in return for benefits received.
The Cairns group has agreed to continue meeting regularly in Geneva in the course of the negotiating process-and also at Ministerial level as circumstances require.
In so doing, it is demonstrating its commitment to ensuring that the momentum and spirit of Punta del Este is sustained.

The ability to harness the strength of the combined forces of the smaller agricultural exporting nations has been clearly established. We must continue to not only maintain, but also build on that new-found strength.

Australia will continue to chair the Cairns group and my Department will provide the necessary secretariat to facilitate continued co-operation and liaison both within its membership and in its dealings with the major trading economies.

The Uruguay declaration introduces some hope where before was only despair. A commitment to negotiate on a broad range of old and new trade policy issues. The chance to redress past inequalities and create an environment for more dynamic world trace growth in the future. It is a commendable commitment of political will.

That commitment will have to be sustained and reinforced over the next four years. For the negotiations to be successful, there will need to be a determined commitment to seek domestic policy adjustments and reforms.
The recognition that radical changes have to be faced is an enormous step. It establishes an environment where national policy makers will look at their policy prescriptions in a new light.

In agriculture, this will also enable us to approach the shorter term surplus problems with more assurance and sense. The Australian Government will be actively pursuing all avenues to redress current trading problems in the months ahead.

Naturally, there was a reluctance to adopt such a broad mandate. Some developing countries in our own region had misgivings about a negotiation that would inevitably touch into the area of domestic policy formulation.

These concerns have been covered by reference to the special position of developing countries. Certainly, we would not expect negotiated outcomes to apply with the same intensity to modest support programs in these countries as would be expected from all industrialised countries and the more affluent newly industrialised countries.
Services
The launching of negotiations on services is another important achievement of the Punta del Este meeting. And again an historic precedent was set.
For the first time we have an international consensus to consider the liberalisation of markets for service industries and to examine the scope for legally binding rules governing such trade.

The services sector is a particularly important sector of the Australian economy. Services now account for 75 per cent of Australian employment and about 65 per cent of GDP. Although Australia has not to date performed well in international trade in services, the sector is well placed to take advantage of Australia's improved competitive circumstances.

Changes instituted by this Government in the area of financial services, and the vitality this has injected into that sector, signal the confidence with which we can approach these negotiations. Although that represents only a first step, our potential to develop into a significant trading force in the sector is beyond doubt.

Certainly our ability to compete in a more open, non-discriminatory international services trade sector will be one of the major challenges faced by Australia in the coming years-a challenge we cannot afford to ignore. It offers more potential to accelerate growth for Australia's export receipts than any other industry sector.
Market Access

The Ministerial declaration calls for negotiations to expand market access by reducing both tariff and non-tariff barriers to trade, and liberalise trade in tropical products and natural resource-based products. Australia is prepared to participate fully in these negotiations.

They offer a valuable opportunity to reinforce the Government's domestic policies aimed at improving the international competitiveness of Australian industry and the gradual development of an outward orientated industrial structure.

Other key features for Australia of the ``Uruguay round'' agenda include undertakings to improve existing GATT articles and codes, particularly the subsidies code, negotiate a comprehensive safeguards agreement on emergency protection arrangements, improve the rules and procedures of the dispute settlement process and look at other ways of improving the GATT institutional framework. This is a broad reaching and complex agenda.
Time Frame

Ministers established a trade negotiations committee (TNC) to oversee the negotiations in the round. Between now and the end of the year the TNC will complete an organisational structure for negotiations and appoint those who will chair the various negotiating groups.
We anticipate that substantive negotiations will be well under way by early next year with a four year target date for completion.
However, in some areas of the negotiations, particularly agriculture, the urgency of the problems are such that we will be seeking concrete results from the negotiations as soon as possible.

The United States has been advocating a special ``Fast Track'' for agriculture. Australia, and the Cairns Group, fully supports this objective. In that light, the Cairns Group will be pressing for completion of the negotiations on agriculture within two years.

The negotiations will vary in length and tempo according to subject. The ministerial declaration notes that agreements reached at an early state may be implemented on a provisional or definitive basis prior to the formal conclusion of the negotiations.

Australia in concert with the Cairns Group, regional partners and other like-minded countries, will be pressing for the earliest possible negotiated settlements. (Even in that case, however, it is likely that implementation of these settlements would take place over several years.)

The real success of Punta Del Este is that a new round of trade negotiations has been launched encompassing critically important areas of trade for Australia in a much more comprehensive manner than has been the case in the past.
It is therefore central to Australia's current economic circumstances.

It offers the prospect within the foreseeable future of a new world trading order that would allow Australia to realise its competitive advantage in agriculture, and would give a major stimulus to employment, investment, and general economic growth.
In short, the Uruguay round of GATT negotiations holds the prospect of a higher standard of living for all Australians. Our task in Geneva is to turn that promise into a reality.

We have a long way to go but we are well positioned for what lies ahead. While there will continue to be frustrations, disappointments and reverses, there is now some room for optimism that world trade can be placed on a more equitable basis for smaller trading countries like Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement relating to the defence policy of this Government and to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The defence policy of this government is to pursue a disciplined relationship between strategy and force structure within the constraint of what is financially feasible in a period of economic stringency. Within this framework virtually every aspect of the defence of this country is being analysed and modernised to meet Australia's real defence needs in the 1980's.

The annual statement of the defence minister necessarily focuses on outlays. It is more appropriate to argue elsewhere aspects of broad strategy. Nevertheless because we have closely linked the three essential elements of defence policy it is necessary briefly to state strategy and what has been achieved in matching it to budgetary possibilities.

It is sometimes argued that what is needed is a statement of the desirable in the structure of the Australian Defence Forces and damn the dollar. This makes great copy but disastrous policy. Such an unstructured approach left us with armed forces undercapitalised when this government took office-an undercapitalisation which was in no small measure due to an inability to take decisions to cut unnecessary capabilities and to reduce inefficiency elsewhere in the program. This left us with some serious gaps in our force structure as amply described by Paul Dibb.

Our strategy is for Defence self-reliance. It is self-reliance against a background that recognises we have regional responsibilities that must be addressed after we have assigned first priority to our own needs. It is self-reliance also within the framework of a wider alliance with the United States. Our alliance and agreements with the U.S. in particular but also with New Zealand and other South Pacific and South East Asian States impacts on strategy, force structure and budget outlays largely in positive ways. We receive at reasonable cost, essential capabilities in the intelligence, scientific and equipment areas which reduce the number of expensive tasks we would otherwise have to perform.

The relationships also help to create a strategic environment which is relatively benign. Unlike many countries, we can say with confidence that it would take years for a potential enemy to develop the military capability to mount an attack on us of sufficient magnitude to destroy our society. We also realise, however, that capabilities for lower-level threats both to our national interests and those of our friends and neighbours, do exist within the region. In this case the emergence of such threats is a product not of capability but politics. A political situation can change rapidly and this government accepts that there is a requirement for it to be able to counter such challenges should they emerge.

It is a pity that the disciplined approach of this government has been the object of opposition sniping based on a combination of deliberate misunderstanding of key elements of government strategy including warning time doctrine and the intellectual sloppiness of unrealistic forward defence strategies that the opposition itself abandoned in government in the 1970s. These ill informed and unco-ordinated criticisms have been accompanied by an absolute determination that no more will be spent on defence than we are spending.

As the leader of the National Party said only last month ``We have got to reduce taxes and frankly I think that has a higher priority for me as far as the Budget is concerned before you decide what you are going to spend on Defence.''
Therefore in the unlikely event of a resumption of office by them, we can expect the gaps in defence which we are closing to be replaced by other areas of deficiency.

This Government is tackling all of the problems the opposition generated or ignored. Our equipment is being updated, our command arrangements streamlined and strengthened, and our factories rationalised. Most importantly we have addressed key aspects of the conditions of service personnel.

We have done so on the basis that whilst all in the community must share some of the burdens imposed by our economic circumstances, unusual burdens should not be borne by the forces. Like all Australians they are entitled to an independent review of their conditions and they have that now under our independent tribunal.

The services are entitled to decent housing. They will get that after years of opposition meandering, through our increased financial commitment of some $66 million in this budget and an independent statutory authority.

The problems of service personnel are complex as Sue Hamilton established in her report. Moneys are being made available in this budget to implement her suggestions for improving the conditions of service spouses and families.

Project management and the defence factories are being reformed so that they can contribute to the exciting industrial opportunities offered by the major re-equipment of the defence force now under way.
The roles and functions of the joint facilities are being explained to Australians with a new honesty and a new respect for the interest taken by Australians in global strategic issues.
The resources to realise all these commitments are coming from real growth in the defence budget, and from major reforms in administration.
This Government's undertaking to increase defence spending in real terms has been met over four consecutive Labor Budgets with an average annual real growth of 2.7%.

The Government's commitment to real growth in defence spending has been amply demonstrated this year. Under the toughest budgetary discipline faced by any government for many years, defence spending has been budgeted to grow by 1% in real terms.

In a year when Government outlays overall have not been allowed to grow at all, this is a remarkable outcome. It is even more remarkable in the light of the severe effect of the dollar's depreciation on the defence budget. The defence budget has been insulated from the effect of the low dollar, which has been taken into account before calculating real growth in the defence budget.

Under this Government, defence spending has reached record peacetime levels. This year's defence budget is $7415 million, an increase of $743 million or 11.1% in actual terms over last year's outlays.
Defence spending this year constitutes 9.9% of Commonwealth Budget outlays and 2.9% of GDP-sustaining the highest GDP share of defence spending since the days of the Vietnam war in the early 1970s.

Within the defence budget, reforms are being made which will save over $30 million in a full year. Rationalisation of the defence factories has resulted in significant staff reductions. Management is being improved and new work practices are being negotiated.

More than eighty per cent of this budget is allocated directly to the defence force for new equipment and facilities, personnel and operations. Three per cent is allocated directly in support of defence industry and production activities, two per cent for defence research and development, one per cent for defence co-operation and one per cent for expenditure by other departments.
Service pensions account for another five per cent and five per cent is for the Department of Defence policy elements and central, regional and overseas administration in support of defence programs.
The key focus in this year's defence budget is long term investment in equipment and facilities, to continue the re-equipping of the ADF with up-to-date capabilities tailored to our strategic needs.
One third-33.2%-of this year's defence budget will be spent on new equipment and facilities, easily the highest for more than 15 years and double the rate of 17% achieved by the coalition in 1981-82.

In all over 130 major equipment projects are underway this year, and decisions will be made this year on many more. The most important of these will be the new submarine project. Within a few weeks we will be receiving tenders from the two submarine consortiums, and a decision will be made in the middle of next year on which company will design and construct our new submarines.

Among the major equipment purchases being made this year are Seahawk and Blackhawk helicopters, PC9 trainers for the Airforce, Steyr rifles for the Army, a wide range of trucks for the Army, harpoon and standard missiles for the Navy and short and medium range missiles for the Airforce and air defence weapons for the Army.
The total of nearly $2.2 billion being spent on re-equipping the ADF this year is directed to reshaping the defence force to meet the specific strategic needs and challenges of our environment.
Priority is being given to high-technology solutions to the problems posed by the unique terrain over which the ADF could be called upon to operate.
Among the most challenging tasks for the ADF is surveillance of the vast areas to our north.
I am therefore delighted to announce the Government's decision to proceed with a major project to develop a comprehensive over-the-horizon radar system to cover the whole of our northern approaches.

Based on the technology developed by Australian defence scientists and engineers of the Electronics Research Laboratory in South Australia through the Jindalee Project, this system will provide comprehensive coverage of air and shipping movements throughout the air/sea gap to our north, far more cheaply than any other system.
It is planned that at least two, and probably three new other sites will be established, one or two in north-eastern Australia and one in the west or south-west.
At the same time further development will be carried out at the existing other site near Alice Springs to refine the equipment and operating procedures.
Total cost of this project, including a network of three stations, will amount to approximately $500 million.

Jindalee is just one example of the Government's intention to develop a force structure for the ADF which directly guards the weaknesses and exploits the strengths of Australia's strategic environment.

Another important project under way this year is the conversion of the RAAF's existing fleet of four 707 aircraft for air to air refuelling of the F/A-18's. We must look continually for useful force multipliers for air operations. Increasing familiarity with problems of interception in and from the north is demonstrating the need for range in our primary air assets and the need for more time on task. So this will greatly enhance the ADF's capabilities to project power throughout Australia's area of military interest.
We have commenced preliminary work on the Navy's next generation of warships, the new surface combatant.

Under this project I intend to seek Government approval to build, in Australia, up to eight ships to meet the requirements identified by the Navy and by Dibb for a large number of light, capable vessels to operate throughout Australia's surrounding maritime areas.

The importance of this project should not be underestimated. It is comparable in size to the submarine project. It will have higher Australian content. It will have greater export potential. It will proceed alongside the submarine project having a shorter start up period.

We regard it as providing the Navy with more decks to perform essential war time tasks in focal points and in support of the heavier warships. In peace time it will give us additional useful capabilities to demonstrate Australian concern for the surveillance needs of our neighbours.

It is hoped that requests for proposals for this project will be issued later this year, and that construction of the vessels will commence in the early 1990's. The project is currently estimated at $2.5 billion. Expenditure this year on major facilities projects includes $70 million on the development of the air base at Tindal in the Northern Territory, $23 million on the construction of an air base at Derby in W.A., and we have decided to provide facilities for the new Blackhawk helicopters at Townsville at an estimated cost of $19 million.
These and other projects reflect the Government's commitment to defending the north of Australia by providing appropriate facilities for ADF deployments there.
In excess of $500 million will be spent this year on developing and maintaining defence facilities and housing around the country.

The Government is seeking to achieve substantial economies in the management of defence assets and operations through management reorganisation, the rationalisation of defence production establishments and initiatives aimed at accelerating the disposal of surplus defence equipment, land holdings, plant and machinery.

The thrust of these improvements has been to delegate responsibility and authority, reduce complexity and duplication, and simplify lines of control. Creation of the office of capital procurement was the first major step in this regard. It brings together the functional areas responsible for the procurement of approved major capital equipment (including financial programming and budgeting) with the areas responsible for procurement policy and procedures, defence industry policy, and participation by Australian industry in the supply of equipment.
Clear lines of authority are now provided for major equipment acquisition through every stage of a project.
The office of defence production within my department now administers fifteen defence factories employing over 13,000 people.

The management improvement programs initiated by this government have had to be complemented by rationalisation of the operations of Williamstown and Garden Island dockyards, and the government aircraft factories. Staff reductions have been made not only at the factory level but also in the central office in Canberra, where a reduction of over 12% has already been achieved.

The government has also decided to close the Albion explosives factory in Melbourne and dispose of the aircraft engineering workshop at Pooraka, near Adelaide. The capabilities of the Albion factory will be transferred to the Mulwala explosives factory.
