The Albion site will be cleared and will eventually be returned to general community use.

I have also announced the government's decision to establish the government aircraft factories as a government owned company. This decision recognises that the government aircraft factories are an important competitor in the Australian aerospace industry and one that is destined to become a more important commercial force.
In these circumstances it makes sense to ensure that the government aircraft factories are placed on the same commercial footing as its private sector competitors.

As part of the process of rationalising our defence industry, the sale and release to Australian industry of Commonwealth owned machinery was begun with a major review in April this year. Nearly 20,000 items are issued on loan or lease to hundreds of Australian companies and those immediately available for disposal are expected to realise at least $14m this financial year with further returns in coming years.

Australian industry will directly reap the benefits of nearly $1800m in the Defence Budget. $380m will be spent on major capital equipment projects, including $82m for the basic trainer, $76m for the Australian built frigates, and $64m on a range of communications and electronics equipment, particularly radios (Projects Parakeet and Raven) and fixed communications (DISCON).

In addition, industry will be substantially involved in projects such as assembly of the Sea Hawk and Blackhawk helicopters and continued work on the F/A-18 aircraft, with the advantages that these activities bring to industry through the transfer of advanced technology, skills and capabilities.
A further $900m will be spent here in the manufacturing and service industries for other equipment, stores and repair.

I have today released details of measures the government has approved to assist Australian industry to bid for defence work and to develop and export military and related products. The list of measures is based on preliminary recommendations from my ministerial consultant, Bob Cooksey, from industry itself and from within the department. Austrade is to become directly involved in selling defence products, the flow of information to industry will be improved, defence expertise, equipment and manpower will be made more readily available and export controls will be reviewed.
In future defence projects, it is our intention to keep Commonwealth ownership of assets to an absolute minimum. This will mean simpler dealings with industry and less bureaucracy.
The government regards the improvement of service conditions, particularly for members of the ADF, as among the most pressing of defence priorities.
The Hamilton report has provided a valuable basis for alleviating some of the harsher aspects of service life. A team has now been established to implement measures to deal with these problems.
Defence housing has been overhauled, with an independent authority being established to administer the 22,000 homes for which Defence is responsible.
Spending on housing will rise by 20% to $66 m.

As part of the major overhaul of conditions of service in the ADF, the Government has established a Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal. For the first time servicemen and women's pay is now set by an independent tribunal, in line with normal Australian practice, instead of by the Government of the day. The Tribunal has already made a general determination on services pay, which produced a rise of 5.9%, and is now to consider certain allowances.

The approved strength of the regular defence force will remain unchanged at 70 529, although actual numbers were below this level at 30 June 1986. The planned terminal strengths for 1986-87 are 15 732 for the Navy, 32 000 for the Army and 22 797 for the Air Force.
The Army Reserve numbers are planned to increase during 1986-87 to 24 500, up from 23 145 at the end of 1985-86.

Resignation rates among officers have been unusually high in recent months. This is partly due to structural factors, such as the passage through the ADF's career structure of a hump originating in the high recruitment levels during the Vietnam war.

High resignation rates also reflects strong job prospects outside the ADF, especially for some classes of highly-trained officers like pilots. The requirement to match salary to rank makes it impossible for the ADF to match the offers that highly-trained young officers can attract from private employers.

But neither the Government nor the ADF is content to assume that such factors tell the whole story on high resignation rates, and the CDF is undertaking a study to ascertain any other factors which may be taken into account in trying to address this problem.

In line with the Government's decisions on rationalisation of the workforce at defence factories and dockyards, civilian personnel numbers overall will decline in 1986-87, in staff years, by some 850. The reduction also includes the rundown in locally engaged civilians at Butterworth, Malaysia. Average civilian staffing numbers planned for 1986-87 are 39 713.

The command structure of the ADF is being modernised and strengthened to meet the demands of a self-reliant defence posture. Increasingly the three services of the ADF are being designed to fight together as one independent force, and this requires that planning and administration of the services is increasingly centralised in HQADF. A major step was taken in this direction in June with the creation of the position of Vice Chief of the Defence Force to co-ordinate the force development planning activities of the three services.
The role of the reserves is also being reassessed as part of the Government's program to optimise the ADF to meet the requirements of our strategic circumstances.
The Government regards the Reserves as an integral part of the ADF, and plans to enhance the functions and responsibilities of the Reserve units to reflect this.

Options are being examined to allocate the Reserves more weapons and roles. For the Army Reserve, consideration is being given to equipping them with heavier weapons including tanks and medium artillery, and to allocating particular wartime functions to specific Reserve units.
Consideration is being given to increasing the use of the Navy Reserve in the mine counter measures area, and maintenance and airfield defence roles to the Airforce Reserve.
Each of these functions would be vital in even low-level hostilities, and the Government is legislating to allow limited call-out of the Reserves in situations short of a declared defence emergency.
Incentives will be introduced to improve recruitment and retention for the Reserve Forces in recognition of their enhanced role.
The Government will restore full taxation exemption of the pay of Defence Force reservists from 1 January 1987. At the same time the special reserve allowance will be discontinued as an offset.
In addition, the government will increase army reserve training days from the budget level of 900,000 last year to 942,000 this year.

All these initiatives will enhance that development of a defence force with capabilities relevant to self-reliant defence of Australia. But we do not do this in isolation. This government recognises the importance to our security of effective relations with regional neighbours and with our traditional friends. It is to these relationships that I now turn.

The Government is devoting increased resources to co-operative defence activities with the Pacific island countries and Papua New Guinea. $34.8m has been allocated to such activities in this year's budget, compared with expenditure of $27.1m in 1985-86.

Much of the increase reflects the gathering pace of the Pacific patrol boat project, which has been developed to assist the South Pacific Forum countries upgrade their maritime surveillance capabilities to maintain sovereignty over their extensive exclusive economic zones.

Countries now participating in the project include Papua New Guinea and Fiji (each of which is to receive four boats) and the Solomon Islands, Vanuatu, Western Samoa and the Cook Islands-which will receive one boat each.

Construction of the vessels is now well advanced at Australian Shipbuilding Industries' Yard in Western Australia; crews are being trained in Australia and the participating countries are developing, with advice from RAN experts in-country, the necessary infrastructure and management systems to receive the boats into service. The first boat will be completed in February 1987.

This project demonstrates the Government's firm commitment to co-operate in practical ways with the south pacific forum countries to enhance the security of our common region. We would hope that they will continue to view Australia as a primary partner in defence matters.
The Government has also made provision for continuing defence co-operation with our ASEAN neighbours, where funds allocated in 1986-87 total some $19.5m.

With the increasing sophistication of these countries in defence matters, co-operative activities are now focused on sharing training experience and the transfer of Australian defence expertise through professional exchanges and consultancies.

The changes which have occurred in the United States/New Zealand relationship as a result of the dispute over ship visits have not affected the fundamental US/Australia relationship under the ANZUS alliance.

When Mr Hayden and I met with Secretary Shultz and Secretary Weinberger in San Francisco earlier this year, we reaffirmed that the ANZUS treaty remained in place, and that the relationship between Australia and the US under the treaty, and the rights and obligations assumed by Australia and the United States towards each other under ANZUS, would remain constant and undiminished.

The same, of course, applies to our wider co-operative defence relationship with the United States which is facilitated by the ANZUS alliance and which includes such mutually beneficial activities as combined exercises, co-operation in research and development, and personnel and intelligence exchanges.
These activities assist Australia to develop and maintain its self-reliant defence capability.

This Government views our alliance with the US as a dynamic relationship, which is being developed and strengthened to meet the evolving needs of both parties. One exciting new development is the agreement between ourselves and the US Navy to jointly develop an Australian Invention-Project Nulka. This will involve our co-operation in the development of a defensive system for surface ships.

The US has withdrawn its security commitment to New Zealand until the port access issue is resolved. New Zealand is well aware of Australia's own views and policies on port access. The issue has not, however, affected Australia's bilateral defence relationship and activities with New Zealand, which derive from long standing, overlapping national defence and strategic interests.

In this statement I have highlighted the main features of the defence budget and indicated this Government's resolve to build a defence force relevant to Australia's self-reliant defence. The Government will shortly bring down a white paper on defence which will provide a clear and practical blue print for the continuing development of the defence of this nation.

This Government has brought to the defence of Australia a new rationale, a new honesty with the Australian people, and new hardware for the armed forces. The Opposition offers old fears, outworn slogans and old equipment.
This Government has an absolute commitment to renew Australia's defences from top to bottom, and an absolute commitment to provide the defence spending to do it.
The Opposition is tied to the past by its 1950's strategic cliches and its absolute commitment to cut defence spending.
Madam Speaker, as a further aid to responsible and reasoned debate on defence I table the 1985-86 defence report.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members and on behalf of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) I table the Defence Report 1985-86. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement which has been tabled by Senator Gareth Evans on behalf of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) is entitled `Post Budget Statement'. It was given in relation to the tabling at the same time of the Defence Report. The statement which has been incorporated is very lengthy. It is a somewhat rambling tour de force of the Defence Department's activities which is very much the same as that which is already, no doubt, covered in the report and in the materials which were tabled during Estimates committee hearings regarding the Budget allocations for defence. The statement is also somewhat repetitive and, generally speaking, one wonders what benefit or interest the Minister believes that members of parliament are going to achieve from this particular exercise. As I have said, except in one respect, it really adds nothing more to the various materials that are already in the public domain. The Government says that it is considering the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities and that a White Paper on that matter will be tabled shortly. But this statement is not a White Paper which deals with defence policy or defence capability; it deals really with the sorts of matters that are contained in the report of the Department of Defence.

SPEECH.PARA: In the early part of this statement the Minister does come back to the defence strategy, the basis of the Dibb report, which has already been adopted by the Government and by the Minister for Defence. When the Minister tabled the Dibb report he talked about our strategy being one of defence self-reliance. He repeats again in this statement the basic concept the Government has, based on the Dibb report, that, unlike many countries, we can say with confidence that it would take years for a potential enemy to develop the military capability to mount an attack on us of sufficient magnitude to destroy our society. The wording that he used there seems to be very much the same as the wording in the Dibb analysis and strategy. It is a concept, of course, with which the Opposition totally disagrees. Since the Dibb report came out and since the subsequent debate on this matter has continued we have made that quite clear. We believe that this is a completely naive approach to the planning of our defence capabilities and requirements. We believe that it flies totally in the face of reality and the experience of the past. When countries have acquired major defence capabilities, as Germany did in the 1930s, within a very short space of time their capabilities were quite sufficient to be able to mount an attack, destructive of our society.

These are matters for further debate in this chamber when we eventually get the Government's White Paper. It will be interesting to see whether the Government maintains that view on long term defence strategy when it puts down that White Paper because it is a view which has been rejected by virtually every major defence authority. The notion behind it seems to be a retreat into the idea of Fortress Australia, which has also been thoroughly discredited as a defence strategy, and which is part and parcel of the Minister's thinking. As I said, he repeats it again here, in light of the tremendous and virtually unanimous criticism by authorities of this particular aspect of the Dibb report-I am surprised that the Minister has repeated it again-it will be interesting to see whether the Government sticks with what has become very much the Beazley view of our defence requirements. Nevertheless, as I said, it is disappointing and disturbing to find that he is repeating it again in this statement, even though the statement is not about that subject but is really about the nuts and bolts of defence activities.

The only new item in what I have described as a somewhat rambling and repetitive statement is his announcement of the Government's decision to proceed with the over the horizon radar system to cover the whole of our northern approaches. The total cost of this project, which is known as Jindalee, including the network for the three stations that are to be established, is approximately $500m-a very major defence expenditure indeed. The Jindalee project is being proceeded with ahead of other aspects of early warning systems, particularly airborne early warning systems, which certainly would be part and parcel of an effective early warning system. There has been, again, a good deal of expert criticism of the sole reliance on the Jindalee system. Jindalee is certainly innovative. It is an Australian concept that has been well researched but it is not fully proved and on its own it is not likely to be fully effective. However, the Opposition does not criticise the decision to proceed with it, but I think it is a matter of criticism that the Minister has not indicated any Government decision to proceed with other and necessary aspects of the same question but solely this aspect of it that, welcome and all as it may be, is not really an adequate solution to the problem on its own.

The statement deals at some length with and claims some Government credit for defence expenditures. It points out that even in this year of restraint there will be a one per cent increase in real terms in defence expenditure. It also points out that the Government in its four Budgets so far has provided an average annual real growth in defence expenditure of 2.7 per cent. The Minister points that out as though it were some achievement of the Government. I do not know how that can be maintained in light of the fact that over the four consecutive Labor Budgets the real increase in expenditure is of the order of 4 1/2 per cent. Defence expenditure by this Government, on the Minister's own admission, is well and truly below the Government's real increases in expenditure across the board. Certainly, the figures do not establish any major concern for the defence of this country. If the Government's priorities are to be judged on the basis of these statistics, it obviously gives a very much lower priority to defence expenditure than it gives to most other items of government expenditure. Those statistics provided by the Minister, presumably in support of defence policies and commitment by this Government, reveal the absolute reverse. They reveal that the Government gives far greater priority to a whole range of other areas-there is no need to go over those-than it gives to defence, when it can spend comparatively so much less on defence than it is prepared to spend on increases in expenditure in a whole range of other areas.

The Minister also seems to be claiming credit for the fact that one third of this year's defence budget will be spent on new equipment and facilities, which he says is the highest expenditure on these matters for 15 years and is double the 17 per cent expenditure achieved by the coalition in its last year in office. Of course, the fact is that decisions made over the years by the Fraser Government on new equipment-such as the F18 program and a number of other major defence equipment decisions, major initiatives in the acquisition of new defence equipment-are now, of course, being reflected in the size of the budget. That is really quite a dishonest use of statistics by the Minister and certainly does not establish the case that he has endeavoured to make.

I think the most disappointing and, in the circumstances, most surprising aspect of this statement is the way in which the Minister deals with the high resignation rates of officers in the Services. The Minister seems to have no concept of the enormity of the problem and the need for the most urgent action to be taken by the Government. As I said, he mentions it. He says that it is the subject of a study by the Chief of Defence Force Staff. He seems to believe that the problems will be solved by some of the actions that have been taken by the Government in relation to service conditions, which I will deal with separately in a minute. The magnitude of the officer resignation rate and the problem presented by it is enormous. It is nothing less than a brain drain in the defence forces of this country and has clearly reached crisis level. In all Services, highly trained personnel are leaving at a faster rate than the rate at which they are being recruited, let alone trained.

In the Australian Defence Force as a whole, 620 male officers have resigned so far this year, which is twice the rate which occurred last year. Losses from the Australian defence forces are now running at almost 10 per cent a year and simply cannot be sustained at that level. Already there are indications from senior officers of the effect that this is having. They are simply having to cut back on functions. The Chief of the General Staff, Lieutenant-General Gration, said recently that the only way out for the Army was to divert manpower from lower priority areas. A senior officer in the Royal Australian Air Force has warned that this year, unless current RAAF losses are stemmed, the RAAF simply will have to curtail its functions. So it is an extremely serious problem which does not seem to be comprehended by the Minister, as evidenced by his laid-back approach in this statement. One would have thought that that matter would have been highlighted in this statement, that there would be real assurances that the Government understands it and will do something about it, and that it could be seen that some initiative was being taken by the Government, but that is not the case. As I said, it is only mentioned towards the end of the statement, and what is said indicates that the Government has not grasped the magnitude and the urgency of the problem.

The Minister makes claims in regard to a number of initiatives in relation to defence personnel. As I said, I think he sees these initiatives as a way of resolving the problem. Clearly, it is not. Clearly, the professional officers are concerned about it. Indeed, reference is made by the Minister to the fact that the CDF is undertaking a study to ascertain what other factors may be playing a part in this problem. The fact is that the Government and the Minister are overstating the effect of the initiatives the Government has taken. It seems to believe that the setting up of the permanent Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal is a major initiative. It is since decisions have been made by that Tribunal that the crisis has come upon the Services. The Government's so-called initiatives in this area are not at all effective.

The comments that have been made about the 5.9 per cent pay rise that was granted indicate that very grave concern is felt following that rise; it certainly has not stemmed the concern. Personnel have expressed a good deal of disappointment and discontent about that pay rise and there has been a considerable consensus that this does not raise the pay level of members to that which they see is earned in civilian life. As I have said, this problem has really arisen since that decision was made; so it is not adequate, and a much more effective approach is required. However, the Government's breaking of its promises on the defence force retirements benefits, with the tax on superannuation lump sum payments and the recent decision of discounting the defence force retirement and death benefits pension by 2 per cent-the legislation has recently gone through this Parliament-contributed to the very grave dissatisfaction which is felt by personnel. Efforts at tackling housing or the Hamilton report on spouses of Service persons are dealing only with the fringes of this problem. The matter seems unlikely to be resolved in the way in which the Minister hopes. In his statement he attaches considerable significance to it.

The statement is clearly a disappointment. It is adding virtually nothing to what is known about facts and figures, nuts and bolts, of defence issues. It is simply repeating the attitudes and views which have been expressed by the Government. We still await the Government's serious response to the Dibb report. Clearly the Government is here indicating a lack of real appreciation, as it continues to do, of the problems of Australian defence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats do not entirely agree with the Opposition on this matter. After all we can hardly expect the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) to be coming up with fresh initiatives in such a difficult and expensive field every five minutes. We feel that in this statement the Government has consolidated, rationalised and put together the sorts of things it intends to carry out in the defence field. On the whole, those are things of which we would approve, just as we approve of the general thrust of the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities which is aimed at a strong and independent Australia, with a degree of self-reliance which we have not had before and a capability to look after ourselves which the Democrats have been pressing for strongly in this Parliament for the last eight years and which was the motivation of our very strong opposition to having such materiel as a short deck aircraft carrier. This would have taken up huge amounts of our defence funding and not given us anything that would have been effective other than in terms of operations with our allies. I would like briefly to address that point because I think that it is important.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important that we should be able to operate with our allies as long as they remain our allies and that is our considered government position. However, I think that our allies would probably be a lot happier with an Australia that had a degree of self-reliance and strength rather than a wandering child who every now and again had to say: `Please daddy, somebody is going to hit me. Come and help me'. That is the deplorable attitude towards defence which the present Opposition had when it was in government. That is simply not good enough for a number of reasons which I will mention when I get a little further into the report. It is an important report and it does deserve some debate in the Senate.

In the statement the Minister is whistling in the dark to a rather large extent. I suppose he has to do that. He may not have gone to the Cabinet and agreed to his Budget being cut; in fact he probably did not, like most Ministers. He omits to say anywhere in his statement that the Budget cuts in defence will militate against progressive moves towards a self-reliant defence structure as was outlined in the Dibb report. That is beyond doubt. One does not buy defence materiel without money and there has to be considered community consensus that that be agreed upon.

Without being unduly war-mongering or pushing the idea that we should bristle with weapons, I believe that the Australian public probably would regard it as a good option that we are self-reliant and that we are able to defend ourselves if that is at all possible. Of course we are now entering the stage when, with modern weapons including smart missiles, it is much more possible for a small country to defend itself effectively than it was in the past. Moreover, it is quite possible for a country to maintain a stance which is genuinely a defence structure because of the nature of that materiel which is not particularly well suited to foreign adventuring, to rushing off with our allies and to blowing up other people's countries which, after the Vietnam war, not too many people in Australia are very keen on.

The Democrats agree that we should have a strong, independent defence capability. I find it a little cause for concern that on page 2 of the Minister's statement the Government excuses itself rather smugly from its clear duty to move significantly towards a self-reliant position with these words:

The relationships also help to create a strategic environment which is relatively benign. Unlike many countries, we can say with confidence that it would take years for a potential enemy to develop the military capability to mount an attack on us of sufficient magnitude to destroy our society.

I think that is unduly smug and unduly short sighted and I hope that is not a basic idea that forms government policy because it would be a great pity if it were. There is no way that a small middle power such as ourselves can assess the state of the world; nor can we guarantee that it will stay the same. We have comparatively little control over the total global situation where wars and alliances are concerned-and we should appreciate that fact and that the world can change very quickly.

The event everybody rightly dreads and fears in the world is a major engagement between the Soviet Union and the United States of America which would almost certainly involve the use of nuclear weapons. This could create situations very different from what the Minister describes. It is possible to foresee a situation, as many people do, that nothing would survive in the world. Unfortunately, that is only too possible. However, there is perhaps a slight chance that if there were a limited nuclear engagement-if such a thing were possible; we do not really know; weapons have never been used on that scale-and the super-powers were badly mauled and Europe was virtually destroyed, it would be a very different world. Those things could happen.

What would happen? Australia would be very much alone and isolated in that world and would be the victim of any kind of foreign adventure which might be mounted against us for any reason. I do not say that that is a likely contingency. We all hope that it is something that will never happen. But I think it is reasonable to put ourselves in the position where we can guard ourselves against it. We must accept that as a possibility in the world. We must be prepared to build up a modern, flexible and effective armed services with the well-trained people and the weapons to defend this country. The Minister uses the words:
. . . mount an attack . . . of sufficient magnitude to destroy our society.

Maybe he sees those last words as a kind of let out. But what about the situation that could arise if we were alone and there was a running sore of spasmodic invasions from the north which were mounted with any degree of persistence or organisation. Such attacks would certainly not destroy our society in a dramatic way in a few days or a few weeks. However, if we were in a situation where there had been a major world conflict and were trying to pull together what was left of our society, we would be placed in a very dangerous situation indeed. This is something which could be avoided. I am one of those people who believe-perhaps I am an optimist-that if this dreaded global nuclear war comes about some human beings and societies will survive. I would say that this society would be one of them. It will survive in our country towns and our widely dispersed areas, It will survive in areas which are largely self-sufficient. Perhaps it will survive in Tasmania. For the same reason, society may survive in parts of New Zealand. It will probably survive in some of the more decentralised areas of China.

If that is the case, the basis of some sort of defence and some sort of organisation of government must be maintained. In that respect I think there is an argument for members of our armed forces to become skilled in all sorts of occupations. They should be the sort of people who are capable of putting in a small water-powered power plant where such a facility is needed; people who have some sort of engineering ability which may be of value to this country at some stage. So, I do not like the Government to make bland statements that we can say with confidence that it would take years for a potential enemy to develop the military capability to mount an attack of sufficient magnitude to destroy our society.

It is quite a few years now since I was in Indonesia and watched members of the Indonesian air force put on a display. On the whole, I did not think that they were too bad although they tend to lose aircraft rather regularly, to crash them and break them up. However, I do not think it would pay for us to underestimate the capability for attack that that society has. Of course, Indonesia is now going in for modern material. Honourable senators in this place have probably heard me rather tediously argue for the need for Australia to get modern missile carriers such as the American Pegasus class hydrofoils which are made by Boeing. These are very fast, cheap, lightly manned and highly effective vessels which have more fire power than any ship we have in our navy at present. The vessels are armed with eight harpoon missiles on light weight launchers. I noticed in reading some material the other day that the Indonesians are now buying these weapons. They are very wise to do so because they are a very effective type of missile carrier in the modern world. It does not matter very much what type of platform a missile is launched from-the missile will do the rest provided that one has enough of them and provided the launch platform is stable. Of course, the hydrofoil conformation is interesting because it is stable in quite rough waves. It is a perfectly stable platform. It has speed and a low profile so it is not easily attacked. We need plenty of that sort of weapon here. The Indonesians understand what is needed and that is why they are buying this sort of thing. I do not think the Government should underestimate those sorts of possibilities.

The Minister makes a further bland assumption on page 3 of his statement which annoys me greatly, as indeed did Senator Durack's comment on the same thing. At the bottom of page 3 of his statement the Minister, in talking about the problems of the armed services, says:
Most importantly we have addressed key aspects of the conditions of Service personnel.

This comes only a week after the Government and the Opposition connived together in this place-this included Senator Durack-to vote for the Government's disturbance, meddling and tampering with Service superannuation. They discounted Service superannuation. The Government broke a clear agreement that it would not tamper with something that was brought into Consolidated Revenue from an independent trust on trust. Only recently that was discounted by 2 per cent by a vote in the Senate. Yet, the Government has the gall to say that it is addressing key aspects of the conditions of Service personnel. It may be news to the Government but if it talked to many Service personnel-I am referring to the professionals such as instructor-sergeants around the place who, I might say, do not get paid all that well for the work that they do-it would find that they regard their superannuation as the bottom line, the mainstay of their future. On the whole, I think they do not care what else one does to them. However, they do not want to have that meddled with. The Government could not have meddled with anything more dangerous and damaging than that. I feel very angry with the Opposition for conniving at that and for allowing that legislation to be passed on the very specious grounds--

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did you support the lump sum superannuation tax?

—I do not know whether Senator Durack made it but I heard it made by Senator Puplick. The Opposition claimed that this was a Budget Bill. Hell, what do they think they are here for. They are here to be members of one House of Parliament that governs this country, not to kow-tow to the Government on Budget Bills. To try to confuse the public about the difference between Supply and Budget Bills is, I suggest, dishonest at the very least. There is no question that the blocking or changing of a Budget Bill will bring about a situation such as that that brought about the downfall of the Whitlam Government in 1975. It is dishonest and specious to convey the impression to the public that somehow the Opposition is being holy by not blocking Budget Bills because it does not want to contrive that situation again. The real truth is that the Opposition wants the Government to do its dirty work for it. It wants to come back into government and find all of those nasty things done. That is why it is doing that kind of thing. Therefore, I suggest that this is not an argument that really ought to be brought up, especially by the Opposition, as being something of any great value.

SPEECH.PARA: On page 5 of the statement the Minister talks about the roles and functions of the joint facilities which he says are being explained to Australians with a new honesty and a new respect for the interest taken by Australians in global strategic issues. He is dead right. Australians are interested in global strategic issues. But I do not think his statement can be justified. The past of the joint facilities is too well known and too well documented to permit any such easy conversion of the thinking public. They are all very concerned about what the role of the American bases-the joint facilities-are. I think the Government has a clear duty to explain more to people what it is all about. If the joint facilities are operated principally for our benefit as well as perhaps for the benefit of the Americans, there is not all that much need for undue secrecy about how these things are organised and done. Questions have been raised time and time again over the years which are begged and which are part of the national ethos. For example, the Government must tell the Australian people whether or not Pine Gap ever was controlled by the Central Intelligence Agency, as I think a former Labor Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam, once said or, indeed, if that is the case, whether it is still controlled by the CIA. The background of the CIA is not such that any country would want that kind of influence operating actively within its society.

Is it a fact, as has been alleged, that Pine Gap does eavesdrop on all the telephone calls coming in and out of Australia. This has been alleged and stated time and time again. Most Australians believe it happens. The Government has a clear duty to let us know whether or not this happens. After all, this is our country; we have sovereignty over it. There is every reason in the world why these matters should be addressed. Maybe they are a pack of lies. If they are a pack of lies, let the Government come out and say so. Let us understand the situation clearly. I think all of us would be very happy to know that.

The Government, if it is determined to keep these facilities, must see that its authority on what happens in our own territory is absolute-not joint, but absolute. For instance, if the very low frequency arrays at North West Cape are now obsolete and are more useful in respect of communication with our own submerged submarines than with those of the United States nuclear fleet-these statements have been made-let that be made clear. Let it be said and made clear if they are not a significant part of the communication with American submerged submarines-I believe that is probably the case; the new technology is pretty well known. If that is the case, let the control of and access to the facility be Australianised. If that is the case, there is no reason why there should be this undue arcane degree of secrecy concerning those areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are saying that North West Cape is no longer a nuclear target, then.

—I am not saying that North West Cape is not a nuclear target. I am glad that Senator MacGibbon raised the point because it is a very important one. It is a fact-I think I can give him references on this; some time I will do it-that if there is a nuclear war, North West Cape would have to be a nuclear target, as will its fellow stations in the United States of America, because they do in fact represent a second line. In other words, a fall back position to using VFL arrays to communicate with those submarines in other circumstances. Therefore, it would be rational and reasonable for an enemy to say: `Okay, this is something which is a backstop'. There is also the other point: While the enemy presumably does not know what is there and if the security is good enough to prevent the enemy from knowing what is there, it is not going to know whether it is worth attacking or not. In that situation the enemy will attack it; it will become a nuclear target. I am glad that the honourable senator raised that point. It is a very important one that deserves some clarification. I do not think it really changes the situation. If the Government took my line and said perfectly clearly to the Russians, `Okay, come and have a look at the place, it is communicating with our submarines and it is not important in the sense of communicating with American nuclear submarines', it probably would not be a nuclear target. The secrecy, the aura of tight security around it, makes it a nuclear target. We are told: `You can't come here. You can't see this and you must not know a thing about this'. Even Australians are not allowed to go there. Therefore it must be important, and if it is important it must be attacked. I think that is an area that the Government might well consider clearing up, as I think that would probably reduce the threat to Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The references to the radar surveillance of our northern approaches-referred to on page 9 of the printed copy of this statement-to which Senator Durack referred, are very important. I felt that he did not give them due regard. I think none of us has any desire to claim the technical expertise to understand this, but I am prepared to believe that there are those working on the project who have and that indeed we probably have got the basis here for a very important situation which can, for the first time, as the report says:
provide comprehensive coverage of air and shipping movements throughout the air/sea gap to our north, far more cheaply than any other system.

That is always desirable. I suggest to Senator Durack that we ought to note that sentence because it is a statement of the Government's intent and I think the Senate has a right to follow it up and make sure that that does happen, as I think it probably will. It is the Government's intent then that is good and the system must be completed rapidly even though it is expensive. That will then end the absurd situation which has applied in the past where we could be invaded in a dozen places by a small army and probably never know anything about it for days on end. That has been, and remains, the situation in Australia, and a very dangerous situation it is when we consider that our supply lines to our remote northern and western areas, with all the effective forces we have now, are a hell of a lot longer than probably those of anybody who might seek to invade us. So we might find ourselves after some lapse of time on the sticky end of the situation rather than otherwise. So it is vital that that surveillance system should be completed. The cost-half a billion dollars-is expensive, but there again I think the Australian people would accept that and not regard it as particularly expensive. It is a matter of real bottom line security. We could comfortably know that if somebody tried to invade or enter this country we would be immediately warned of it and able to take some preventative action.

I again think that the Opposition has not given anywhere near enough support to the Dibb report in its areas where it attempts to create a flexible strike force which could then go quickly to that area and deal with any kind of invasion. I think it is only reasonable and honest to give the Government and Mr Dibb credit there. That is something which is valuable and important. I think that it is very, very unlikely that we will be invaded from Antarctica or New Zealand. If there is ever a threat to this country it will come from the north west or the north. Therefore we must be prepared to be able to move into those areas forces which are highly professional, highly trained and as well armed as they can be. And that would include an army with a very large and important airborne parachute capability. It would also involve having weapons in the northern part of the country which were capable, in the first instance, of deterring those invasion forces as quickly as possible. The knowledge that we have in sufficient numbers aircraft such as the FA18 and perhaps small ships which are efficient missile platforms would be sufficient in itself, I think, to deter any attempt at a seaborne or airborne invasion of Australia. I think a seaborne invasion is the only thing that we could look at as being practicable. I do not think it would be feasible for any country that I can think of in our neighbourhood to invade this country and to supply its troops by air. Therefore the ability to strike at and destroy ships is very important.

We have missiles, and the Harpoon missile is one we have standardised. It is expensive but efficient. There is no reason why we should not have as many carriers, or as many decks, as the statement calls them, as we reasonably can to convey those weapons at an invader. People talk about the Phalanx system which we now have. Phalanx is fine; it throws huge quantities of lead or sometimes depleted uranium in the form of slugs at an incoming missile, and it can destroy that missile. It can probably destroy a second one or even a third, but if a large salvo-eight, ten or fifteen-of missiles is attacking a ship armed with Phalanx, there is no way in the world that most of those will not hit home and destroy that ship. There is no defence system capable of preventing that. That, I think, should give us some guide as to the way we ought to regard our defences; we should have vast, flexible carriers which can attack in large numbers with missiles.

That brings me to the final point which I want to discuss in this report, which I think is also very important, and that is the references to the new surface combatant, which is a very interesting statement. I have never struck that phrase before. The new surface combatant is a new generation of warships which the Government is planning for Australia and which are very important. The Minister says:

. . . I intend to seek Government approval to build, in Australia, up to eight ships to meet the requirements identified by the Navy and by Dibb for a large number of light, capable vessels to operate throughout Australia's surrounding maritime areas.
The importance of this project should not be underestimated. It is comparable in size to the submarine project. It will have higher Australian content. It will have greater export potential.

That is an important point, because when I was talking with Mr O'Flynn, the Defence Minister, in Wellington, New Zealand, he raised this point with me. He said that if Australia were making small ships and things of that kind it would be very much in his country's interests to buy them because there would be compatibility. That is very important to us. So I think we have an export possibility here, not only to New Zealand but also to the other Pacific countries. That point is not mentioned here but I suggest that it is something that the Minister could think about.

There is one thing which the statement does not say and which I think ought to be brought home and ironed out as soon as possible: These ships, right from the start, should have missile capability and we should not make the same terrible mistake that we made with the Fremantle class ships, which are for their time of building and size first class small warships which are quite capable of being efficient missile carriers. As they stand now, I think each ship has a World War II type Bofors gun on the foredeck. Officers have told me that when there is any sort of a chop and the ships are travelling upwind the guns are incapable of putting a shot over even a Taiwanese fishing boat's bows. There is no excuse for this. This is a terribly bad piece of planning. The idea apparently was to make a small patrol ship which would be rather more comfortable to travel in than the ones we had before, and that idea is laudable to that extent. But having got those ships it would at least have been reasonable to equip them. I was aboard HMAS Fremantle not long after she came into commission and I was shown the places where control systems and missiles could be put. There is room in the ships to do the work. If we get on to this new surface combatant vessel, let us for heaven's sake not turn out another abortion, a so-called warship which is not capable of fighting; let us provide it with that capability of attack if an invading fleet ever tried to reach this country.

I am no particular propagandist for Boeing and I should not be pushing its interests-I have not got any shares in Boeing, I will say that right now-but we should look at the Pegasus class hydrofoil, which is now being built in a stretched out version and which has much better and more comfortable crew quarters than the original Pegasus, which frankly was worse than most submarines, and that was a grave deficiency. There are certain advantages. The engines are the same as those in the FFG frigates, so there is compatibility there. A lot of ships can be built here under licence, and the engines, the guns-Oto melara 76 mm-and the front foil are about the only things that would have to be imported. These ships are very lightly manned, something like 21 or 22 people, and they are relatively inexpensive. As I said earlier, they are each capable of carrying eight Harpoon missiles on lightweight launchers. They have the quick firing 76 mm Oto Melara gun, which can engage an enemy quite separately, as an automatic quick firing gun. It is a very useful facility. They also have foil launchers which enable them to be pretty good at dodging missiles. There is a point there. These ships are extremely fast. Their top speed is classified, but they are probably the fastest warships in the world. Once they are foil-borne, they have enormous speed of acceleration and are capable of moving well out of the way before incoming missiles find the foil. They are less susceptible to damage than, perhaps, a ship with a displacement hull. The general nimbleness and the low profile of the ship when it is foil-borne make it, of course, much less likely to be a victim, even for wire-guided torpedoes, because they can outrun the torpedoes without any difficulty. I still say that the Government ought to have that flexibility of thinking when it comes to consider the role of the surface combatant. It should not necessarily feel that it ought to have the all-age ships the same. There is a difference of role, a difference of necessity and a difference of requirement in Australian waters, and different circumstances which should be taken into account.

Beyond those points, the Democrats feel that the statement is an interesting recapitulation-I agree largely with Senator Durack-of what the Government has said it is doing in the defence field. We think that the Government is going along the right lines. There are small deficiencies and problems, some of which I have outlined. On the whole, if the Government takes those considerations into account, we might get somewhere at last, after all the decades, the centuries, of creating an Australia which is, for the very first time, reasonably capable of defending itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The paper presented this afternoon by Senator Gareth Evans, the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, is a very immature document. It is strong on emotion and weak on reason. It is a very disappointing document. It is the sort of document that would be presented most fittingly to an Australian Labor Party branch meeting in the western suburbs of Sydney or Melbourne. Those on this side of the chamber regret very much that the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) has not maintained the bipartisan approach to defence that we seek to maintain. We try to emulate the example set by Sir James Killen for a bipartisan approach. Defence simply cannot be a matter of party politics. This document just reeks of party politics and cheap point scoring.

SPEECH.PARA: Defence cannot be a matter of party politics because it involves the security of everyone. Everyone contributes to it with his tax moneys and, if the need arises, with his life. A government needs to have the support of the whole community with its defence policy. All the defence forces in the world are not worth anything unless the government is seen to have the political will to use the defence forces it possesses. The government cannot have that political will unless it has the support of the community. If it has a good defence force, if it has the political will to use it when the essential interests of the country are challenged, we have peace and we do not end up in the business of fighting wars and all the terrible consequences that come from that.

This paper incorporates many of the holy cows, the mythology of the Labor Party. It starts with a statement that we are getting the best defence that the Government thinks we can afford. The proposition that Defence might need a little more money is ridiculed by the Minister in his statement. Money spent on defence, provided it is spent constructively, is money well spent. The state of having no war is the cheapest state we can have. Any war we get involved with involves us in enormous costs, in lives and in money.

One of the central themes of this report is the claim of undercapitalisation. Senator Durack made the point that this was a blatantly dishonest statement. It is blatantly dishonest, because the Government simply has no choice in the amount of money it has to spend to honour the defence contracts that the Government has. Those contracts, by the way, were written by a previous government. This Government has not faced up to the fact that as the cost of new capital equipment has risen, it has continued to cut into that part of the budget in the defence vote that goes for operational capabilities. When we started this some years ago, we did that with the clear expectation that it was for the short term. We were also devoting a lower percentage to capital equipment. We knew that in time it would go from about 17 per cent-a figure cited by the Minister-in the early 1980s, up to the 30 per cent that it is running at now; but we had the intention of increasing the defence vote so that the operational training and capabilities of the Services were not cut back. But the Government has not made that compensatory move, with a consequence that we have the morale problem and the diminution in capability of the defence forces which characterises them today.

The paper puts the case for self-reliance. From my first day in this Senate over eight years ago, I have always supported the view that Australia's first responsibility is to itself and that we could do a great deal more to develop our own independent defence position. I do that in a responsible way, recognising the fact that in a high technology age we have to be supported by other countries in respect of weapons systems and munitions. In this paper, the Minister uses a self-reliant posture in a jingoistic way, trying to pander to the Left of the Labor Party and all the pacifist, non-aligned movement feelings that there are within his Party's ranks.

There is a great statement on page 2 about the fact that we are living in a relatively benign region. Nothing could be further from the truth. It was a benign region 10 years ago, but the tide has turned against us. Looking at the nations that surround us, we have difficulties. New Zealand has gone down a path that has taken it out of an effective defence alliance with Australia. We have Father Lini in Vanuatu doing deals with the Soviets. We will almost certainly see port facilities granted to the Soviets in the near future, and quite probably landing rights for Soviet aircraft. We have the French muddling in New Caledonia-persisting with the techniques that they used in Algeria and, before that, in Vietnam, totally mishandling an independence movement. We will quite likely see Libyan insurgents and other people operating in that country. In Papua New Guinea we have a rundown in the Administration. There are internal problems, and there is a breakdown in law and order. There is a difficult border relationship between New Guinea and Indonesia. The Philippine's problems are far from resolved. Mrs Aquino is trying to cope with a very virulent communist New People's Army. The future control of the Philippines is anyone's guess. Our relationship with Indonesia has been exacerbated by the incompetence of this Government in its foreign relations. The 65-year-old President Suharto, after 20 years of responsible rule of Indonesia, will be replaced within the next five to seven years. No one knows what policies will be followed by the Indonesians after that. On top of all of that, we have a very active exercise by the Soviets to project power both politically and militarily into the area.

Yet the Minister makes the claim that we are now in a very benign region. He links that to the old hoary cliche that we have had 10 year's peace, that there is no threat for 10 years and all that sort of thing. It is very dear to the Labor Party. The Minister ought to read a bit of history. Things can change, and they can change very dramatically. From the night of 7-8 December 1941, when the two Royal Australian Air Force squadrons were bombed in Kota Bharu, in Malaya, as it was then, it was under eight weeks till Rabaul was taken by the Japanese on 23 January 1942. That was with the very poor transport and very poor communications systems that existed over 40 years ago.

This Government has got this country's defences in the position where we simply have no ready reaction capability. The Operational Deployment Force can project only a brigade after one month's warning, and it has no sustainability in the field. In simple terms, it cannot fight for more than a matter of days. The Air Force cannot fight for more than a couple of days, nor can the Navy, because we are holding no real stocks of munitions or of missiles in this country.

I want to deal with the point in the report where the Leader of the National Party of Australia, Mr Sinclair, the shadow Minister for Defence, is quoted-and in a way that appears to be quite damaging to the Opposition's case. What was being said by Mr Sinclair-which is lifted out of context-was the very important point that before we worry about how we are going to spend money on the Department of Defence or any other department, the first thing is to get the economy right, because we cannot have an effective defence force unless we have a strong economy. I will not take the time of the Senate this afternoon to reflect on the incompetence of this Government in the economic field. What we would do with the Department of Defence is eliminate the waste that led to the loss of $70m by the bungling of the trainer program this year. That $70m has not given one cent of benefit to the Australian community. We would streamline to remove the incompetence in the vast civilian bureaucracy in the Department of Defence.

In the statement, a great deal was made about the percentage of the vote this year going to equipment. As I said before, the Government is locked into this contractual position. In the main, the contracts were written by the previous Government. The present Government simply has no alternative but to honour the obligations that it has to those contracts.

The position is made worse by the disastrous handling of the economy. For example, when we wrote the contract for the FA18s in the early 1980s the Australian dollar was worth about $US1.25. This year's estimate to the Department of Defence used a trade-weighted average of $A0.52 for $US1. That has more than doubled the cost of the equipment that we have on order. The trade-weighted average is down to 52c simply because overseas people have no confidence in the way Keating and Hawke are running this country. The Minister talks about the equipment that he will buy. I would have thought that one of the first requirements of a Minister for Defence, as part of his independent posture, is to buy what he can in Australia. Yet, in the last 12 months we have seen many hundreds of millions of dollars being spent unnecessarily overseas on equipment.

The first matter was the Air Force trainer contract in respect of which we lost $70m-with no benefit at all-on an Australian design. The management of that project, not its concept, was at fault. If the Government had any ability it would have made something out of the situation and saved the $300m or $350m it will spend on buying a Swiss aircraft. We could have bought Australian, provided far more work for Australia and created a nucleus for the Australian aircraft industry. Another point is the purchase of the new Steyr rifle for the Army. There is absolutely no hurry to get this weapon. There are in this country people who can design and build rifles and small arms. They were not considered by the Department of Defence because the Government was not interested in what Australians can do. We proved well over 40 or 50 years ago that we could build arms. Something as simple as a rifle, the equivalent of a bow and arrow in earlier ages, must be built in Australia, Again, we have written a contract for hundreds of millions of dollars for an Austrian rifle, when that was unnecessary.

The recent order to buy new trucks to add to the purchase of Mercedes Benz unimogs also could have been completed in Australia. The Army truck that is being replaced, the International F1, needs only a diesel engine. Either International, if still in business, General Motors-Holden's Ltd or the Ford Motor Co. of Australia Ltd could build a suitable and adequate truck for the Australian defence forces; but again, the Minister goes overseas with a contract that is worth hundreds of millions of dollars. I will not start on the armoured personnel carriers and the nonsensical position we are in by sticking with a 30-year-old first generation vehicle. We will buy kits from overseas, again probably at a cost of hundreds of millions of dollars, to modify them.

I will briefly deal with the over the horizon radar because from a news point of view it is obviously the thing about which the Minister will puff his chest out and hold a Press conference in an hour or so. He will make a big thing out of it. The first thing to say about the over the horizon radar, the Jindalee program, is that there is nothing new about over the horizon radar. It works by using a high frequency signal which bounces off the ionosphere, is reflected down to the earth and then is reflected back along the same path. It has been looked at for very many years-since the inception of radar-but the problems of making it work are such that it has not been adopted as a universal substitute for conventional shorter wavelength radars.

Australia's peculiar situation, with the absence of the borealis and so on and our geographic position, optimises the use of an over the horizon radar system. Undeniably, this is of very great benefit to Australia's defence, but in no sense is it a complete and effective radar coverage. There has to be some priority. We must have radar coverage around the northern sectors of the Australian continent because at present we have no idea what is coming into or going out of this country. We are within range of USSR aircraft operating out of Cam Ranh Bay. We are within range of the Indian BEAR Fs that are operating from Indian bases. They can overfly a large part of our continent. I do not doubt that they do so from time to time, particularly on electronic intelligence flights. We need to know what is going on.

Our first Jindalee system is in its development phase. The big problem is that it requires a very complex computer program which analyses signals and makes sense out of them. The system must be made reliable and predictive. We have years of work in sorting out the first Jindalee system. To go ahead now and buy another two or three systems means that we will put all our eggs in the one basket, a basket that we know very well technically has a lot of holes. We ought to develop the one radar station we have at present and buy some aircraft for airborne early warning. Even when Jindalee is worked up to its peak of operational efficiency, it is only a trip-wire.

It is very easy to jam that system. It must cope with changes in the ionospheric layer, which is unstable. It is subject to diurnal variations which will affect any high frequency radio signal. Targets which are moving circumferentially and which have no Doppler shift cannot be identified. Having said that, it is is a very good trip-wire. We will know when something is out there; but we then have to go out and find out what it is. We find out what is out there with an AEW aircraft. I am opposed to buying two or three more over the horizon radars at present because there is no justification for them; there are higher priorities in the radar surveillance field.

The ministerial statement also refers to the conversion of four Boeing 707s for in-flight refuelling purposes. This is long overdue but, again, it is too little and it may be too late. People think that if we buy one or two tanker aircraft we can supply the whole of the Air Force. One tanker cannot be assigned on any mission; there must always be two. There must always be a back up. It might do the Senate some good to realise that, on the first bombing operation from Ascension Island to the Falkland Islands, one Victor bomber of the Royal Air Force was assigned and 16 tanker aircraft were required to support that one strike aircraft. That is an extreme case, but the point I make is that four aircraft give only a training facility, not an operational facility. We need many more of them. The obvious way to provide that capacity is by using internal tankage in the C130s or, prefer- ably, to buy new ones that have the wing plumbing to take a fuselage tank and dispense it.

The proposition is also defective because the tankers would service only the F18s, and the F18s provide us with no deterrent capability. I want to pick up the point that the previous speaker laboured about flitting around in Pegasus patrol boats that are an absolute technical and operational failure. The US Navy had an order for a large number of Pegasus boats. It received its first four or six and then chopped the order because the boats were hopelessly expensive, short ranged and generally useless. They are used to chase people on surfboards in the Caribbean. They are not used in an operational role. The previous speaker raised the point about raiding parties coming to the north of Australia in a harassing role and said that these people could be chased away with patrol boats. We will not chase them away with patrol boats. The only solution is to remove the bases from which they operate. To do that one will have to use F111s. It cannot be done with F18s. The need to provide boom refuelling for the F111s is as important as the need to provide probe and drogue refuelling for the F18s. Yet the Government makes no attempt at all to provide this most necessary air-refuelling for the F111s.

The deterrent capability of the Australian defence forces is its prime role. Unlike the proposition put forward in the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities that we go back to a garrison Australia with barbed wire starting on Bathurst Island, letting aggressors seize the initiative and legally come to within 12 miles of the Australian coast, as they can, with offensive ships and aircraft because they are legally entitled to, and trying to defeat these forces when they cross onto the Australian mainland, we on this side of the chamber believe that we must have a deterrent capability. This means that we can strike at the bases from which any potential enemy might operate against us.

The Minister refers to the new submarine program. I am sorry that he does not go into some details. This program is subjected to very considerable cost overruns. We are involved with two designers, HDW/IKL and Kockum's. They have never built boats of the complexity or size that Australia requires. They are meeting technical problems. It is a very high risk program. It is also a very expensive program. The Australian taxpayer is entitled to some explanation as to how this program is going. We on this side of the chamber are very concerned about statements from the Minister supporting the proposition in the Dibb report that, as the program is subject to cost overruns, we could accept some reduction in capability. Being diesel electric submarines, the improvement in operational performance these submarines have over the existing Oberon boats is marginal. It is only a matter of degree. There is no quantum jump at all in what the new submarines will do. Considering the great sum of money that is involved, if we are to cut that capability-and cut it probably to the same or less capability of the Oberon boats-it simply does not make sense to proceed.

The Minister seems to have adopted a very irrational stance with respect to these new submarines. He is very emotionally involved with them. He reacts to any criticism of the program. He will not even answer legitimate questions about what is going on. One is left with the impression that he is emotionally committed to signing a contract for these submarines, irrespective of whatever technical or financial problems are involved, and wants to get it done before the election next year. The Minister should reflect on the fact that Sir James Killen was in a similar position with respect to the F18s. It is a matter of public record, in an article by the Chief Defence Scientist, Professor Fink, that Professor Fink went to Sir James Killen with a problem with the F18 some months before the election in 1980. He said: `I need more time to consider this problem and make sure that we get it right before we sign the contract, but I know, Minister, that you want to sign this contract to get the benefit for the coming election'. The Minister of the day said to him: `You fix the technical problems. It is quite improper for me to try to get any political milage out of such an important contract by signing it before the election'. It is a matter of history that that is what took place. The contract was signed after the election was held.

There is a lot of verbiage about the pay and conditions of the Services. People are leaving the Australian defence forces in record numbers because they are not appreciated. They feel that they are wasting their time. They have been subjected to pay restraint, their allowances have eroded to the point where they no longer have much meaning. Simple things such as re-engagement allowances are not considered. Little things that can be done to improve the lot of the servicemen meet no favourable response from the Department. The consequence is that morale is worse than it has ever been in our peacetime history. We probably have fewer people with defence obligations in Australia today per head of population than we had at the time of Federation.

Recommendations of the Hamilton report on Supporting Service Families, which was a good report, are funded to a miserable degree in this year's Budget. I forget the figures, but I think out of a commitment of $20m to fix the problems, this Budget provides about $2m. It is totally inadequate. It is not a sincere approach to the problem. The situation of the reserves is abysmal. The number of effective reserves is about half the number it should be. Probably about 15,000 or 17,000 reservists are efficient with respect to their training obligations. That is because the pay and conditions are so poor. I could go on for ages. The stewardship of the Department of Defence under this Government is an abysmal failure. We on this side of the chamber think that this paper is quite inadequate and lacks responsibility. The subject demands a far more responsible approach than this paper gives it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the Government's basic concept of self-reliance in presenting this paper to the Parliament. However, it comes as something of a contradiction when it is so firmly rooted within the framework of the ANZUS alliance. There is a contradiction in terms: How can we be self-reliant if our first loyalty is towards the ANZUS alliance? I believe that our view of the Soviets is quite different from the United States view and would probably be more in line with the Japanese view. Japan sees the Soviet Union not as an enemy, as it is perceived by the United States, but as a vulnerable adversary with which dialogue must be maintained. That is the position most Australians would have with regard to the Soviet Union. Certainly our defence and foreign relations policies should not be so influenced by the United States that its enemies immediately become our enemies.

SPEECH.PARA: In the same way, when on page 2 of the report the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) talks about regional security, we have to be very mindful of the needs of our South East Asian and south-west Pacific neighbours which, I believe, have been shamefully ignored by the United States in recent years. I believe that the recent buildup in the militarisation of the Pacific, to which Senator MacGibbon referred, is largely due to the fact that the countries in that region have felt abandoned by the United States, certainly in the economic area, and that for their security they need economic security. Many of those countries rely, for example, mainly on fishing. In that regard the United States has an appalling record. Its tuna boats have poached fish from the Pacific island nations. Now that the Soviet Union has entered into fishing agreements, it is doing just what the United States Government should have done many years ago-concluding proper fishing agreements for which it pays fishing rights to the countries in whose waters it wants to fish. So I believe that we need to keep in perspective the fact that relationships within our region should be based on the needs of the peoples within the region and not on perceptions as they might emanate from the United States.

The countries in the region have cried out for economic security. I believe that cuts in foreign aid, as were brought down in the Budget, are also greatly regrettable. We have shown a lot of concern, for example, for the starving in Africa this year and have worried about growing instability in the South Pacific region because of the Soviets getting a possible toe-hold there. But at the same time, the island states of the South Pacific have repeatedly told us that their real security lies in economic security and in aid being channelled into community development projects where appropriate.

We have cut aid to the South Pacific by 9 per cent this year, while military aid to the region has increased by 70 per cent. We should take into account the fact that overseas aid is a very good way to build good relationships in the region. Self-help development projects, not the provision of more military aid, would be appropriate in producing the economic security for which the nations in the region are crying out. I think it would also help to reduce the threat perceptions in the region if we were seen to be assisting countries in our region by involving ourselves in foreign aid programs rather than in military aid programs or by the acquisition of sophisticated, long range offensive equipment, as we are doing at the moment. That only increases the threat perception in the region and gives great difficulties to our neighbours who, I am sure, would like to see us in a much more benevolent light.

I think we need to consider the nature of modern warfare, nuclear warfare aside. Since the Second World War, there have been very few wars which have been conducted after the declaration of a war. Wars have emerged as either wars of liberation or as struggles by minority groups or by terrorists. Most of these wars are not declared and peace treaties are not signed at the end of them. We have to take into account the kind of modern warfare that is being waged and consider the threat perception to Australia in that light. It is unlikely that any nation will attempt to undertake a full scale invasion of Australia. There have been many Government reports to that effect, particularly the 1981 Katter report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence which said that the only country that had the capability of launching such a full scale attack with any likelihood of success was our great friend and ally the United States of America. So we do need to consider that if other countries have Australia on a hit list, particularly the Soviet Union, it is only because of our alliance relationship with the United States. If the Soviet Union wants what Australia has, it can trade with us much more cheaply than it can go to war with us over our resources, for example.

We need to look at the defence equipment which this report is mostly concerned with. We buy 70 per cent of our equipment from the United States-second only to Saudi Arabia in dependence on the United States for military hardware. I agree with what Senator MacGibbon has just said about the need to produce much more equipment within Australia. We can do that and also diversify our purchasing power by looking to other countries. In this respect, the Government must be commended for deciding to build the eight new light frigates in Australia and also for letting the submarine contract to a country other than the United States. The recent history of the treatment of Australia by the United States in economic areas, particularly in relation to sugar and wheat deals, has shown that we are indeed naive if we think that Australia should get a good deal from the United States merely because we are involved in a military alignment with it. There is no reason why Australian farmers should get a better deal than American farmers, but this fact has highlighted for many Australians the absurd situation that exists between the United States and Australia where we buy 70 per cent of our defence equipment from it and it buys virtually nothing from us. It is a very unequal imbalance indeed.

We need to look at our defensive defence capability. That is what is actually needed for Australia. Essentially we need weapons that are primarily defensive in nature and not offensive. I totally reject the concept of forward defence put forward by the Opposition and which has just been repeated by Senator MacGibbon-that we need to be ready to go out and demolish the launching pads from which people may be thinking of mounting attacks on Australia. That is exactly the kind of thinking that increases tension levels within the region and it needs to be totally rejected.

We also need to look at the magical mythical 3 per cent of gross domestic product traditionally spent on defence.
