I think it is a level that is artificially maintained and that if the defence dollars in this country were spent more wisely and tailored to Australia's unique needs, we would not even need to spend that amount of money on defence. That is not to say that we should not be looking after the Services in Australia and the people who are involved in defending this country. Of course we need to do that, but I reject the notion that we need to be spending a great deal of money on long range offensive weapons systems which in many cases are tailored to suit the needs and requirements of the United States military rather than to suit the requirements of Australia's own unique needs.

We need also to look at Australia's role in the arms trade. Just recently the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) made a statement to the United Nations in New York where he very strongly called for an international agreement to ban all arms sales to countries at war, preparing for war or using arms to suppress human rights. There would not be any country in the region to which Australia is selling arms that does not come under one of those three categories.

Next week the Cooksey report will be brought down in the Parliament. That report is referred to on page 15 of Mr Beazley's statement brought down today. That report recommends that Australia should increase its level of armaments manufacture and get into the business of exporting arms. Australia is already twelfth on the world list of arms exporters-it falls a long way beyond the most important of them-and the countries to which we export our arms are largely countries that are using those weapons to suppress human rights and they are very largely countries in our own region; for example, the Philippines and Indonesia. I think that we should look again at trying to make money out of that kind of situation. It is totally morally reprehensible and the Foreign Minister said that very clearly in his statement to the United Nations on 1 October. There is a great contradiction between what he has said as Minister for Foreign Affairs, with an understanding of the need for good neighbourly relations within the region, and Mr Beazley's statement which will be further exacerbated by the Cooksey report when it comes out next week or whenever it comes out.

What I believe we need to be looking for in Australia is civilian based defence. That does not rate one word of mention in this report and there is not one cent for funding the teaching of conflict resolution and negotiation skills to diplomats. There is not one word about increasing the level of foreign languages that our diplomats speak when they are sent to foreign posts. This is the kind of good relationship area which is totally ignored by the Department of Defence. These things are much cheaper, I might add, than the procurement of expensive and sophisticated weapons systems which are not necessarily going to serve Australia's unique defence needs but which are, as I said before, only going to support our debilitating nuclear alliance with the United States. It is that area which I find is so totally missing from the report and I think it is a great shame that we are not looking at all at civilian based defence and not looking at all the negotiating skills or conflict resolution mechanisms by which a lot of the tensions that build up in this part of the world-indeed, in any part of the world-can be averted.

I believe that Australia has a great opportunity to serve the world community in this respect, if only we would spend money to teach those skills because, indeed, they do need to be taught to diplomats, who otherwise flounder around in diplomatic language and worry about crossing t's and dotting i's and not really getting very far in substantial negotiations because they have not got the skills. I think we have just seen an example of that in Reykjavik where the leaders of the two super-powers would have done very well to have prepared much better for their summit than going there, each with a position that was intransigent, so that they could not come out with any substantial agreement.

I would also like to refer to the statement on page 5 about the joint facilities in Australia to which Senator Mason has already referred. The three-line comment on the so-called joint facilities is insulting in the extreme because Mr Beazley talks about a new honesty in relation to the bases, but he gives it only three lines. It is a shameful lie that there has been any new honesty in dealing with the matter of these so-called joint facilities. There has been no official word about what goes on in the joint facilities except for the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in June 1984 to the Parliament which told us nothing that we did not already know and which was carefully checked by Washington and the Pentagon before it was made.

Subsequently, of course, there have been the glossy photographs of Pine Gap, which Mr Beazley was very proud to present to the media some months ago. He must have in mind the notion that a picture is worth a thousand words. But again the pictures did not tell us anything. They just showed us these magnificent radomes, photographed in the very best light, and told us nothing about what actually goes on underneath the covers of those radomes. There can be no sovereignty in this country without information. The people are being kept in the dark and that is a totally unacceptable situation.

Australia's security needs would be best served by being good neighbours within our region, not by being tied into the debilitating nuclear alliance which increases the threat perception for not only our region but also for the whole world. Australia should be working from an independent and nuclear free position, which would be a great step towards security through peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a post-Budget statement by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). Whatever else this statement is, it is not a statement on defence policy. It is one of the most curious statements I have seen before the Senate. It is essentially a propaganda statement which, indeed, contains a considerable number of inaccuracies and assertions that do not stand the test. It gives a new meaning to the term tautology. It uses words to confuse. The opening statement, which I think says `whatever the threat, we have to do the best we can with the money we have got', reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The defence policy of this Government is to pursue a disciplined relationship between strategy and force structure within the constraints of what is financially feasible in a period of economic stringency.

I commend that as being the superlative in tautology. I would have thought that could have been expressed slightly better. The ministerial statement is based upon the strategic guidance that was given to the Dibb review by the Government. It contained these kinds of assertions:
Australia faces no identifiable direct military threat and there is every prospect that our favourable security circumstances will continue.
There is no conceivable prospect of any power contemplating invasion of our continent and subjugation of our population.
It would take at least 10 years and massive external support for the development of a regional capacity to threaten us with substantial assault.
These judgments about warning time which have been endorsed by official strategic guidance for over a decade now are key concepts for our defence planning . . .
No country has ever blockaded a continent surrounded by seas such as Australia.
Most military activities involving disruption of Australian trade could be handled by evasive routing . . . Australia has the potential to become highly self-sufficient in basic commodities.
Those are quotes from the strategic guidance and they are repeated in this so-called post-Budget statement. It states also:

Unlike many countries we can say with confidence that it would take years for a potential enemy to develop the military capacity to mount an attack on us of sufficient magnitude to destroy our society. We also realise however that capabilities for low level threats both to our national interests and those of our friends and neighbours do exist within the region.

One needs to look at history. It has been said that we learn from history that we learn nothing from history. Certainly this Government and this statement can prove that. I remind the Senate that over the whole course of history-whether it be Pitt the Younger, Lloyd George, Curtin or any other person-we have never been able to predict a threat. I ask the Senate to remember these things: There was no significant warning time of the Berlin blockade, the Korean War, the Malayan emergency, the Iran-Iraq conflict and the invasion of Afghanistan. All those things happened in modern times. I remind the Senate that the escalation of the Vietnamese war-and the development with Russian arms of the North Vietnamese Army as the world's third strongest army-was not foreseen.

Coming closer to this comforting thought that nothing could happen in our region for 10 years, one should remember that even in 1939-40 nobody believed that the Japanese offered any threat to the area. The military appreciations that I studied to get my Army commission were full of statements that the Japanese could not go to war, they had myopic vision and they had an industry that could not survive. Such statements were being made within a year or two of the war. Closer to the war-not 10 years, not five years but 305 days from the biggest war we have fought so far, World War II, the war in which 40 million people were killed-on 2 November 1938 in another place the then Leader of the Australian Labor Party, a great Australian, John Curtin, said these things:

Defence expenditure must depend entirely upon the conditions which prevail in the world from time to time. Obviously that must be the position. I say that any increase of defence expenditure after the Munich Pact so far as Australia is concerned appears to me to be an utterly unjustifiable and hysterical piece of panic propaganda.

That was said 305 days before the greatest war this world has seen, before 40 million people were put to death. This is no reflection on John Curtin; it is a reflection on the nonsense of governments that depend upon the theory of foreseeable threat. Of course that theory is defective in itself because of a fundamental; that is, the lead time for the purchase and acquisition of modern warships, aircraft, equipment and the training of key personnel is far longer in years than any telescope can foresee a threat.

We must understand that the forces in existence today in a country, together with the decisions made today for their expansion or contraction and re-equipment, are the actualities available to a country-to Australia-in most of the decade ahead. What we have put in an order for will take the best part of this decade to be delivered. It takes four years to train an army sergeant and six or seven years to train a subaltern or army captain. It takes seven to 10 years to order and to get a warship. Therefore, it is absolute nonsense to say that we are not in any way vulnerable.

The defence demands of a country should be looked at on three levels: Firstly, what role shall we play, in however small a way, in trying to preserve world peace. We must try to stop all significant wars breaking out. We must try to stop not only nuclear wars, no matter where that first missile may land; we must try to stop any conventional war involving the interests of nuclear nations because undoubtedly that could escalate into a nuclear conflict. We now face a problem that no other people in the world's history have ever faced-how to outlaw war. Since 1945 there have been no less than 120 conflicts in 71 nations with 20 million people killed in conventional wars. These were not nuclear wars but 20 million people were killed. Every year the money spent on conventional arms, not nuclear arms, amounts to $800 billion. In fact, that is nearly 90 per cent of the money spent on all arms. Paradoxically, nuclear arms are the cheap ones in this situation. Most of the money spent on armaments is spent by countries purchasing arms to shore up their particular kind of dictatorship and hegemony.

We must look at our role in maintaining peace. There is no sense at all in isolation or neutrality, in saying we will have nothing on our shores, no ships in our harbour and no installations, because no nation, however isolated, can be immune from a nuclear war. No matter where it starts, no nation can survive a nuclear war even if the missiles do not land on that nation. The facts of the nuclear winter are known to us all. Chernobyl has sent a message aground the world. The message has not been understood. The radioactivity escaping from near Kiev in Russia went through nuclear free zones with the same deadly impact and devastation that it went though non-nuclear free zones-right across Western Europe into the Scandinavian countries and the United Kingdom. There can be no isolation. We must play our part both in overcoming misunderstandings and suspicions in good diplomacy and in sensible defence to ensure globally that there never is such a war. We must play our part in regard to the Western alliance and the ANZUS Treaty. Of course, the Australian Democrats and Senator Vallentine are totally opposed to any kind of alliance. They are totally opposed to the ANZUS Treaty, the Western alliance and any kind of association.

TALK.START.PARA: —Totally opposed to nuclear war-as you should be, but you encourage it by your remarks.

—Let me say this: The demagogues of this world try to say, simply by mouthing a plea for peace, that they are the peacekeepers. That is nonsense. I could read out the history of the 1930s, when people like Senator Sanders, as demagogues, mouthed words which caused the disarmament of the United Kingdom and Western Europe, leaving them vulnerable to the nazi attack. The true peacekeepers of this world are the people who take the deterrent steps to stop war. Let us not believe that the Democrats or Senator Sanders have any monopoly on peace. That is the ugliest thing I know. No demagogue can be more ugly than the one who says: `I have a monopoly on peace; you are all warmongers'. The real defenders of peace are those who are willing to prevent war, and that is what we are doing by way of the Western alliance and the ANZUS Treaty.

SPEECH.PARA: Not only is there a world commitment; there is a commitment on the regional scene. There is a need for us to be good neighbours. I remind the Senate that although we would not know it from the defence statement-indeed, the Dibb report makes no provision for it-we have a number of commitments. Under the ANZUS Treaty, we are part of the Western alliance. Under the five power defence arrangements we participate in the air defence of Malaysia and Singapore. Without any formal commitment, we are heavily involved in Papua New Guinea. We have defence co-operation agreements with the states of the Association of South East Asian Nations and with some South Pacific states. We have a longstanding commitment to Thailand under the South East Asian Defence Treaty, which has never been revoked. We have an obligation under the United Nations Charter to provide forces if the Security Council so requests.

I challenge the Senate to look at either the Government's defence policy or the Dibb report and show where any of those commitments are provided for. In fact, the Dibb report states emphatically that these commitments should not place any demands on defence; the first and major demand being for the continental defence of Australia. It is a policy of destruction and disaster for one to retreat from one's duty for peace on the world scene, for one to retreat from one's commitments on the regional scene, by saying: `We will prepare purely for a defence of our continent and we will prepare on the basis of defence by denial'-a defence by denial which limits one's ability to deter the opponent. Senator Vallentine makes the grave mistake of believing that if one has a deterrent, one is an aggravator. The fact is that if Western Europe in the late 1930s had had a sufficient deterrent, there would have been no nazi commitment to war, and 40 million would not have been killed. Fundamentally, we need that deterrent.

The whole of this policy statement-which reflects the Dibb report-ignores any overt need for us to take part in ANZUS. It talks about ANZUS, but it does not give any overt commitment. It ignores our regional commitments. It simply mouths a series of concepts which are, in themselves, propaganda. For example, as Senator MacGibbon so ably stated, it pretends that the high commitment to capital works and equipment at the moment is an invention of the present Government. Senator MacGibbon made it abundantly clear that the capital works and equipment for which the Government is paying today reflect very largely, if not almost solely, the orders that were placed by a previous Liberal government. I refer to fundamental items such as the FA18 and the big decisions that were made in that regard. Let the Labor Party rejoice in the mistakes it has made, such as in regard to the Leopard tanks.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the FFGs?

—And the FFGs-the frigates. Let the Government rejoice that it committed this country to spend billions of dollars on frigates which could not take a helicopter on the stern in rough weather because it would bounce off and be destroyed. The frigate could not house in hangars on its stern Sea King type active sonar helicopters, which are vital for our anti-submarine warfare defence-the kind of helicopter that was envisaged would be acquired. These are the kinds of defence decisions that were made.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Government wants to take some solace in thinking that it has a defence system that it can be proud of at the moment, it should look at the Hansard record of committee hearings, which show that the Opposition asked: `Tell us about the operational deployment force in the Lavarack Barracks in Townsville. Tell us what we could do if we had an emergency on the shores around Australia'. Honourable senators should bear in mind that the whole thrust of the Dibb report and this statement is that we should have a defence force which can react with immediacy to any attack on our perimeter. We were solemnly told by the brigadiers that if such a thing happened, within seven days they could get an Army company to react. A company comprises about 150 soldiers, give or take 10 or so, about 100-odd soldiers in the front line and support troops. So if we had a complaisant and quiescent enemy who would wait for seven days, we could put a company into action. This is the basis of what is called a vigorous and active defence system. It is nonsensical, After a fortnight they thought they could get a battalion into the area. Of course, if there were raids on our continental shores, there would need to be immediacy of reaction. The Government's policy is based on pretence.

If one wants to test whether the Government has a good defence policy, one has only to look at the failure in regard to retentions within the forces. The fact is that in recent years the number of voluntary retirements in the defence forces reflect the low morale that exists. Each of the forces has shed numbers very badly. There can be no more vivid impression of how the defence system is seen by the people of Australia than to look at the Army Reserve. Numbers in the Army Reserve has been at the 30,000 mark. Numbers in the Reserve-which has formed the basis of the defence system in previous wars-have fallen away. Despite a multi-million dollar advertising program, which showed a Prime Minister smiling benignly while sitting in a helicopter, what has happened?

TALK.START.PARA: —The resignations increased.

—Instead of our recruiting more voluntary servicemen, recruitment declined. Why has this happened? If one wants to test whether this is a good defence policy, who better is there to ask than members of the defence forces? There is no one better to go to than the officers, the servicemen and women, and ask them: `Is it worth while to stay in the Service? Is it a Service that, in terms of its equipment can do its job? Is it one that looks after you?'. We should ask any ex-serviceman about the two per cent reduction in his pension. We should ask him whether he feels happy about this. After all, as far as I can remember-I hope I am not wrong-the only government in the history of the Federation that has ever cut pensions was the Scullin Labor Government in the early 1930s.

SPEECH.PARA: We have a very interesting situation at this moment, a situation in which the morale both of the people inside and outside the forces is being attacked on all sides. One has only to read the Hansards of the Defence Estimates committee hearings or listen to the evidence given. Did anyone want a more bizarre situation than the cross-examination on, shall we say, the M113 armoured personnel carriers? These are 30, 40-year-old vehicles which are obsolete and which the Auditor-General has condemned outright as being dangerous, inefficient in terms of their weaponry and terribly dangerous to the servicemen who use them because they do not provide protection. What does this Government do? It abandons the Waler project that the previous Government set up to get new vehicles.

I ask the Government a number of questions: What has happened to the upgrading that the Auditor-General said should be done? He spent a year looking at this matter. How long will it take the Government to decide what to do regarding the upgrading of these armoured personnel carriers? Do the Government say that it would take three weeks or three months? Not one little bit; the Government said in this chamber that it will take another three years. The Government has taken one year to think about it, it will take another three years to think about it and it told us that after that it may take another one or two years to carry out the repairs. So nobody had better want to use the armoured personnel carriers in the next 3, 4 or 5 years.

We have the extraordinary situation of the world knowing that the Department of Defence has lost ammunition from its munitions factories. Evidence was given that although no explosives at all had been stolen a person was charged and was before the courts for stealing and having ammunition in his possession. This kind of muddled evidence is before us.

The simple fact is this: This Government has put together a policy to appease the left wing of its Party. The Government knows that the ANZUS Treaty is correct; it knows that the installations on its shores are correct; it knows that it should be looking at regional commitments but it has to appease the Left which has the clout inside the Caucus of the Party. So the Government produces what it purports to be a benign strategic situation. Nothing will happen, so one does not need a defence system; one does not need to have anything overtly to support the ANZUS Treaty, the Western alliance or our region at all. All we need is some forces to look after the perimeter of Australia and only then will we be able to deter an opponent after that opponent has left his shores and is on his way to Australia. It is not a matter of deterring by the knowledge that an opponent had better not come here because his bases could be knocked out if he made an aggressive move, which is the logical situation. That is not what will happen at all. We have defence by denial, a situation which has basically emasculated the defence forces. However, it has done more than that. It has shown to the United States of America that we are unreliable allies, that we are basically people who are not willing to play our part.

From day to day we hear nonsense talked by the Australian Democrats and the nuclear disarmament people about the installations on our shores, the ships in our harbour and Exmouth Gulf. Let me make it abundantly clear-it must be said 100 times-that the whole of the conference on disarmament in Geneva over many weeks of debate and discussion and many papers said that if one great peacekeeper is to be named in this world it is the surveillance satellite because it sees what is going on in other countries and it becomes the fundamental deterrent. Therefore, the surveillance satellite should be protected by both sides. The conference on disarmament is attempting to get a treaty to ban any attacks on or destruction of the satellite. Why? It is because it is the best peacekeeper there is and it must not be destroyed; it is the best way of stopping war.

Basically, if one has to have a satellite one has to have Pine Gap and Nurrungar. It hurts when I say this because the whole of Senator Sanders's stance falls down before him when it is known that the 40 nations at the conference on disarmament say that the kinds of installations at Pine Gap and Nurrungar are the world's best peacekeepers. All of those nations are in some kind of conspiracy, according to him, and only he and his people know the truth. Let me simply say to him that the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, said: `If we are to have that treaty we must protect Pine Gap and Nurrungar because they are the receiving stations for the satellite'. Of course that argument was accepted. The kind of destructive propaganda that is told to the young people of today is that we have something on our shores that is very dangerous. The fact is that 40 nations on both sides of the Iron Curtain say that the best way of eliminating danger from this world is to have peacekeeping satellites. Nations agree that deterrence is the key to keeping peace until we can get a non-nuclear defence system, whether it be the strategic defence initiative or otherwise, until we can get a system that will ban all nuclear missiles.

Let me make it abundantly clear that the Liberal and National parties for which I work and support believe that we have to eliminate all nuclear missiles and conventional war from this world. They will work towards a system that will set up a non-nuclear defence system, whether it be the strategic defence initiative, Star Wars or something else. Those who knock the search for a non-nuclear defence system are doing great harm. If Star Wars is no good, if it is a failure, why has it been of such significance in Iceland? Let me make it perfectly clear-and everybody should understand this-that America has said that step by step it will keep no secrets to itself. It will make its information available to the Russians and to others so that no one can be one up on the other; so that we can get disarmament step by step, by putting aside nuclear weapons and taking in non-nuclear defence systems until there are no nuclear weapons.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you believe that?

—I believe, because this plan has been put before the American Congress and the people of the world, that step by step this is the way to peace. I do not believe that by mouthing peace and calling others warmongers one does other than create destructive mischief in this world and that is the only thing the Democrats do very well.

—by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented. Senator Vallentine in her speech said that I proposed a system of forward defence. I did not. I have no support at all for a system of forward defence and sometime, at a later date, I will explain and dispel Senator Vallentine's ignorance of what is a system of forward defence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —It really saddens me that a man of Senator Sir John Carrick's experience has failed to learn and grow with the times. I am sure he has a great grasp of history; I am sure he lived through a very horrible part of the world's history but he has not learned to project that to the modern day. Basically he is still fighting World War II with a World War II mentality and I think this is very unfortunate.
—I am stopping World War III.

—As the honourable senator says, he is fighting World War III. His views will lead to World War III because basically what he wants is increased weaponry. He supports the Star Wars initiative. Of course, we all know that Star Wars, far from being non-nuclear, in fact uses nuclear weapons. It uses a nuclear laser to--

—I take a point of order. Senator Sanders deliberately misquoted Senator Sir John Carrick's interjection. Senator Sir John Carrick said that he was stopping World War III. Senator Sanders deliberately misquoted him, saying that he was fighting World War III. I think he ought to withdraw.
—There is no point of order.

—I do not think it is a point of order either; it is a delaying tactic. About all that a Tasmanian senator can do is delay. They very rarely-certainly this is true in the case of Liberal Party senators-contribute very much to discussions of the sort that are before that Senate at the moment. Senator Sir John Carrick's support of Star Wars or the strategic defence initiative will lead to the start of World War III. He is doing this by encouraging and, in fact, giving comfort to an American President who has been sold a bill of goods. Of course, both Senator Sir John Carrick and Ronald Reagan want to believe that SDI will somehow bring about peace. But, it cannot. SDI can never do so because basically it is a device which can only work if a first strike is launched before it needs to be used. In other words, Star Wars, if developed-scientists agree on this-will not be 100 per cent effective. The only way it can possibly work at all is if 90 per cent of the Soviet missiles are already destroyed in their silos before they can be launched. This is why SDI is not a peace keeper or peace bringer at all.

SPEECH.PARA: In this discussion on defence I think it is important to define who is the enemy. Who is the enemy? On this side of the House, the enemy is obviously the Reds, the communists, this undefined but despised force which somehow is going to take over. Senator MacGibbon said that Vanuatu and, perhaps, the Philippines had this capability of going communist and somehow threatening us. That is utter rubbish. I do not think that anybody in this chamber can honestly say that Vanuatu is a threat to Australia. It can never be.

What about Japan. In Senator Sir John Carrick's mind, Japan, of course, was a threat. I think we still have this feeling about the yellow peril. Is Japan a threat to us? ANZUS, after all, was framed to defend us from Japan. But Japan already has access to everything that it wants from Australia. In fact, we are keen to give it to them. The Liberal and National parties have been very keen to pay the Japanese in the form of massive subsidies to take away our resources, certainly in the form of woodchips and minerals. So the Japanese do not want to invade us.

What about Russia? Is Russia physically going to invade us? Of course not. Russia simply has no capability nor no will to invade Australia. Certainly, Russia would like to take over the world's economic system. I am sure that it would be quite happy if everyone were communist in economic terms. However, Russia has no military designs on Australia. There is no way that that country could even launch an attack on Australia if it wished to do so. It has no capability of carrying out a war so far from its own borders. It is having a terrible time in Afghanistan and all it has to do in that part of the world is roll trucks across the border.

I noted with some sadness the perversion of the nuclear winter argument by Senator Sir John Carrick who seemed to take some satisfaction in the fact that in a nuclear winter we would perish along with the rest of the world and that the Chernobyl disaster showed that radiation would not obey any nuclear free zone signs and would flow across nuclear free zones as if to belittle those zones and say that we should not have them at all. What a nonsense. I am sorry that Senator Sir John Carrick has chosen to leave the chamber. Oh, he is here, but he is not in his seat. I would like Senator Sir John Carrick to listen to what I am saying because I feel it is an unfortunate--

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I draw your attention to the state of the House. Until the honourable senator is a little more honest, I will keep on calling quorums.

—Please do. I think the whole House should hear this. (Quorum formed) I urge honourable senators to stick around. After all, now that we have them in the chamber, why not stay and participate for a change rather than rushing off to their rabbit warrens. As I was saying, the expectation of a nuclear winter after a nuclear war should not be used as an excuse for building more nuclear missiles, for throwing up our hands and saying: `Well, we had better go along with whatever the United States wants because we are all going to die in a nuclear holocaust anyway'. In fact, scientifically that is not even true. Nuclear winter, while it will affect the northern hemisphere to a great extent, probably will not do much damage to Australia or any other countries this far south in the Southern hemisphere. I think it is really a sad commentary that the pro-nuclear forces in our community say that the nuclear winter is a reason for us to continue our harbouring of the United States nuclear powered and armed ships in our ports and the presence of the United States bases which make us a nuclear target. Why doubly compound this system? Without the presence of the bases, without the ships, we simply would not be a direct nuclear target. The nuclear umbrella is an absurdity.

SPEECH.PARA: I had occasion to write to an organisation in the United States of America called the Centre for Defence Information. I asked specifically for two bits of information: Firstly, whether the USS Missouri would be nuclear armed; and secondly, what were the implications of the neither confirm nor deny policy for Australia. I am sure that the forces of the Right, new or old, would maintain that the Centre for Defence Information was made up of a bunch of Reds and communists and such. However, they actually are not. They are very high ranking officials and officers in the American military. The Centre for Defence Information is composed of Gene R. LaRocque, Rear-Admiral, USN (Ret), Director; Eugene J. Carroll, Jr, Rear-Admiral, USN, (Ret), Deputy Director; William T. Fairbourn, Major-General, USMC (Ret), Associate Director; Kermit D. Johnson, Major-General, USA (Ret), Associate Director; James A. Donovan, Colonel, USMC (Ret), Associate Director; and James T. Bush, Captain, USN (Ret), Associate Director. I received a reply from Captain James T. Bush who said:
Dear Senator Sanders:

In answer to your communication of 19 September 1986, it is virtually certain that the USS Missouri, like the other IOWA-class battleships, will be fitted out with nuclear-tipped Tomahawk Land Attack Cruise Missiles (TLAM/N).

This conclusion is based on the following statement made by U.S. Navy Secretary John Lehman in testimony before the Defence Appropriations Sub-committee of the United States House of Representatives earlier this year.

`Two years ago we began deploying Tomahawk sea-launched cruise missiles equipped with nuclear warheads for theater nuclear deterrence. They are now operationally capable on attack submarines, cruisers, destroyers, and reactivated battleships.'
Captain James T. Bush went on to say:
It is possible, of course, that no nuclear missiles are currently on board the Missouri.

However, the collective opinion of the retired naval officers at the Centre for Defence Information is that ships on extended deployments, such as the Missouri's current deployment, carry as close to a war-time load of weapons as possible in order to be prepared for contingency situations.

Here is an admission by some very high ranking United States naval officers that in fact the Missouri was nuclear armed. The other question I asked was about the implications of the confirm nor deny policy and Captain Bush, kindly replied to this letter by writing:

I have been asked by Senator Norman Sanders to comment on the consequences of Australia's acceptance of the United States' Navy's refusal to confirm or deny the presence of nuclear weapons on particular ships.

Under the 1951 ANZUS treaty, Australia, the United States, and New Zealand have pledged to `act to meet the common dangers' resulting from `an armed attack in the Pacific Region on any of the Parties.' This treaty has been beneficial to all of its signatories and existed without challenge for over 30 years-
in saying this James Bush indicates that he is a proponent of ANZUS; fair enough, that is his opinion-

In 1986, however the US responding to the New Zealand government's earlier prohibition of nuclear-propelled and nuclear weapons-capable ships, said that it considered New Zealand to be in violation of the treaty and that therefore the US no longer felt any legal obligation under the treaty to New Zealand.

It is my view that the US severely overreacted to New Zealand's action. New Zealand's decision not to accept the United States' Navy's policy of neither confirming nor denying the presence of nuclear weapons on particular ships did not reduce the value of the ANZUS alliance in any way.
It did not reduce the value of the ANZUS alliance in any way, said this naval captain. He continued:
It need not have impaired the military efficiency or effectiveness of the alliance. And it was not a breach of New Zealand's obligations under the ANZUS treaty.

The same would hold true if Australia adopted a similar policy. Though U.S.-Australian military ties are significant, most of them would not be affected by a ban on port visits by nuclear-propelled or nuclear weapons-capable ships.

The U.S. has 741 active duty military personnel in Australia and numerous intelligence and military facilities. At Pine Gap facility near Alice Springs, the U.S. conducts a wide range of intelligence activities including receiving data from reconnaissance satellites at the Joint Defence Space Research Facility. At North West Cape, the U.S. maintains one of the U.S. Navy's six facilities for communicating with submerged submarines using very low-frequency transmissions. The U.S. also maintains nuclear and seismic test detection stations at various locations.
None of these operations need be affected by an Australian decision not to accept the U.S. Navy's either confirm nor deny policy.

The U.S. does use a port and airfield at Darwin. B-52 bombers conduct maritime surveillance from an airfield at Darwin. However, these aircraft can carry out this function without nuclear weapons on board. Nuclear-capable ships call at the port of Darwin. As a naval officer with 25 years experience in naval operations including service as Executive Officer of two submarines and commander of the USS Simon Bolivar, a nuclear powered submarine, I can say with confidence that port visits have nothing to do with training naval forces for combat operations at sea. Port visits are wonderful opportunities for rest, recreation, and personal adventure, but they don't contribute to military readiness.

I would like to add that the U.S. Navy's neither confirm nor deny policy cannot be justified on the basis of denying information to the Soviet Union. The extensive publicly available information about the U.S. Navy's nuclear arsenal plus Soviet intelligence capabilities means that if anyone knows which U.S. ships are likely carrying nuclear weapons, it is the Soviets.

Australia, like New Zealand, is more than entitled to exercise its right to make its nation a nuclear-free zone if it wishes. This is particularly the case when this right can be respected without detriment to the military readiness or national security of any of the parties to the ANZUS treaty.
The letter is ended: `Respectfully, James T. Bush', who is a US Navy retired captain. I wonder how the Opposition would reply to this.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will never know; most of them have left.

—There are none of them left. They would probably call the man a rank communist. In fact he is a patriot. He simply does not want a nuclear war and he understands that nuclear weapons are unusable to him as a military man. Clearly this neither confirm nor deny policy is designed to keep Australians in the dark, not the Russians, and it is a convenient way for the Government to suppress debate on whether nuclear weapons should be entering our ports at all. I think it is time for the Government to come clean and to state that these ships are carrying nuclear weapons, which we all know, and to stop the charade.

SPEECH.PARA: The neither confirm nor deny policy is now dead and buried. I think Rear-Admiral Martin dug the grave for that policy when the fleet came into Sydney and he said that of course they are nuclear armed but that the weapons are not dangerous. It is time we accepted that fact that they are armed. It is time we accepted the fact that their nuclear arms do make us nuclear targets. The presence of the US bases make us nuclear targets. We must not follow the road which has been outlined by the Opposition which basically will lead to another war. If we keep preparing for a war by increasing armaments for a war, we will have a war. The only way to peace is through disarmament.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Government has tabled this discussion paper on this very important subject which has been of concern to the Opposition for a number of years. This matter was taken up by the Joint Select Committee into the Family Law Act 1975, which the Opposition established. That Committee recommended a collection agency for maintenance because it was quite apparent, during the deliberations of that Committee some years ago, that there was not an adequate means of enforcing the payment of maintenance by non-custodial parents. Indeed all sorts of schemes were being entered into whereby non-custodial parents were able to maximise the contribution of the taxpayer towards the financial problems that arise from a breakup of a marriage. Towards the end of the Fraser Government, which was in office when that report was made, both the Department of Social Security and the Attorney-General's Department were working on schemes to implement the recommendation of that Committee.

When this Government came into office it virtually ignored this problem for some time. The Attorney-General's Department had an inquiry into the question of a maintenance agency being established, and reported on it in 1984, nearly two years ago. But in fact the Government did nothing about that until the end of last year, when it set up a ministerial committee, which has now come forward with this proposal contained in this discussion paper. The paper makes the very clear statement that it is the Government's firm belief that all children have a basic right to be supported by both their parents to the best of their ability. The Opposition fully supports that principle. We are certainly very interested in the scheme that is outlined here for deductions at source through the taxation system of schedule of maintenance which people would pay according to their income. However, the Government has not firmly decided to adopt that principle but it has decided to ask for comment on a number of problems.

These are problems that, as I have said, have been identified by the Opposition, namely the inadequacy of the level of maintenance, the problems in the Family Law Act which require courts to take into account the availability of pensions to the custodial parent as against obligations which should be met by the non-custodial parent and several other deficiencies in that Act. The Opposition sought, in the debate on the Family Law Act in 1983, to remove the provision of the Act which requires courts to take into account the availability of social security payments to custodial parents, and at that time that amendment was in fact opposed by the Government. Towards the end of last year, on behalf of the Opposition, I introduced further amendments to the Family Law Act to give effect to a number of problems which the Government has at long last identified in this debate. Although that Bill was not fully debated in the Senate, Senator Evans, on behalf of the Government, rejected some of its provisions, including the removal of this provision, which this discussion paper now identifies, along with other mat- ters in the Family Law Act, as a very serious problem. These matters were the subject of proposed Opposition amendments to that Bill. Certainly, we are pleased to find that the Government has finally been converted to the principle that it espouses in this paper, a principle which has been firm policy of the Opposition for some time and to which we have sought to give effect by steps taken in this chamber to amend the Family Law Act to, as we could not do in opposition, establish a maintenance collection agency or system. The Government has certainly gone one step further in proposing this maintenance collection system. It is an interesting proposal and one to which the Opposition will certainly give close attention. I hope that the community will respond and comment on this paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that the Government deserves some congratulations for bringing forward a discussion paper on a matter which is of considerable concern to a large number of people in Australia. The paper, is, in fact, a reflection not only of national concern about the welfare of children but also, as it acknowledges, a reflection of international concern about the welfare of children following the breakdown of marriages. New Zealand and a number of States in the United States, including Wisconsin, have in past years had a look at the problems that have developed as marriages break down, particularly with regard to the care, maintenance and welfare of children. It is appropriate that this discussion paper on child maintenance be entitled `Child Support'. It is worth while for us to remember that our primary concern about the breakdown of a marriage from which there have been children is that those children are adequately supported. We must not lose sight of that fact that the care and support of children, and the parents' primary responsibility for that, is a major issue facing us.

SPEECH.PARA: From time to time we get rather excited about other issues resulting from the breakdown of marriage, including relationships between the parents, the problems with access, the damage that one parent can do to another by bad- mouthing the non-custodial parent, and so on. In doing that, we sometimes lose sight of the fact that the most relevant factor is the welfare and well-being of the children of that union. That, of course, is what we have to focus on and it is what this discussion paper focuses on. That is what the Government has asked interested people in the community to focus on when they respond to this paper. It is unfortunate that the Government has given a fairly limited time for community comment. It is an issue that has excited considerable concern-not always, I might add, concern that is directed at the welfare of the children-in the community in recent times.

There is no doubt that we have to look at things such as the level of maintenance that is paid for each child when a marriage breaks down, and the regularity of payment of the maintenance to those children, and a number of other questions have to be resolved with regard to whose responsibility it is to maintain those children, what other things get in the way of it, and how those issues can be resolved. It is noted that this is often considered both general and idealistic, but nevertheless I suggest that it is a definition of health which is totally consistent with the sort of definition that the Australian Democrats see as important in the formulation of health policy. It is one which we carry through into other policy areas, given that we understand the importance of the whole social context, and that policies such as an environment policy, a social and community services policy, individual rights policies and others are all important in the general area of community health.

Many important issues are raised in this report. For instance, one which bears considerable attention is the issue of the impact on health of advances in medical science. As the report says, dramatic scientific or technical advances may not significantly influence the health of the population at large in a positive way. We really need to bear that in mind. Of particular interest are the groups outlined as being at additional risk within the whole context of community health. DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the eightieth report of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances on its activities over the past 12 months.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The report I have just tabled is regarded by the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances as one of considerable significance. Firstly, as the eightieth report of the Committee, it is evidence of the long tradition which has existed in this Senate of bipartisan scrutiny of delegated legislation. Secondly, as the fifth report tabled by the Committee in the past 12 months, it is evidence of the Committee's active response to the legislative complexities of modern government. Nowadays, governments make use of delegated legislation to achieve their aims, instead of resorting to residual bureaucratic discretions that might otherwise be undisclosed. This is the proper and preferable approach to take. Thirdly, as a detailed report which comments on a wide range of instruments, it is hoped that it may become a reference for policy advisers and legislative drafters. The Committee hopes that the report will indicate the pitfalls to avoid when they are preparing delegated legislation.

I will refer briefly to two important aspects of the report. Firstly, during the year the Committee received a number of ministerial undertakings to amend delegated legislation in the interest of personal rights and liberties. Among these were the following undertakings: To restore a right to a jury trial for property offences in the Australian Capital Territory regardless of the value involved; to remove provisions empowering magistrates and justices of the peace to issue search warrants by telephone, as the Committee considers that superior court judges alone should exercise this remarkable power unless Parliament gives it to others; to amend an ordinance dealing with acquired immune deficiency syndrome to ensure that a statutory defence granted to hospitals did not provide a defence to a claim arising out of a negligent blood transfusion; to amend regulations which allowed one department to give to other departments unrestricted access to confidential information about individuals collected by that department; and in respect of certain regulations to provide criteria for decision-making, to provide that reasons for decisions and notices of appeal rights be given and to provide that decisions of officials be subject to rights of appeal.

The Committee pays tribute to the Ministers who gave these undertakings and, indeed, to all Ministers who have given undertakings. The Committee has found that all the Ministers with whom it deals recognises the Committee's bipartisan role, its neutrality on questions of policy and its ability to effectively identify provisions which intrude on civil rights and liberties. Secondly, in its report the Committee draws attention to a number of serious flaws in the Acts Interpretation Act and the Seat of Government (Administration) Act. These are the Acts in which the Senate's powers of disallowance are found. Chapter 2 of the report describes the flaws. The first flaw concerns those provisions which permit delegated legislation to prejudice the rights or entitlements of individuals retrospectively.

The second flaw concerns the anomaly that, although each House of Parliament has a power of partial disallowance over Australian Capital Territory ordinances, there is no similar power of partial disallowance over federal regulations and other instruments. This is a serious defect in the power of disallowance. From time to time sets of regulations are made which incorporate in one single regulation several detailed provisions. Sometimes these contain a new schedule substituted by a single regulation. Sometimes a single regulation contains many detailed sub-regulations. Part only of these provisions may infringe the Committee's principles. Indeed, a single clause only may be the sole objectionable part of the provisions. In these cases, the lack of a power to disallow part only of an instrument is an unacceptable flaw in the disallowance procedure. The Senate has to assess the merit of removing a number of good provisions in order to overcome a single bad provision. This flaw should be remedied as a matter of priority.

The third flaw concerns the drafting of the 1982 amendments to the Acts. These amendments make it unnecessary to table delegated legislation to give it validity. It is legal for delegated legislation, which included delegated legislation infringing human rights, to be made to operate for 15 sitting days without being tabled. On the sixteenth sitting day it becomes void but it is effective till then. Further, it can be remade and a cycle established. This is a serious flaw because delegated legislation is made not only by Ministers, whom we can confidently expect not to take advantage of this gap in the law, but also by numerous statutory authorities and bodies over whom a Minister may have little effective control. Tabling is the procedural device by which the Parliament and the Senate, as a constituent of that Parliament, is alerted to the exercise of delegated power. The present tabling provisions ought to be strengthened as a matter of priority.

The fourth flaw concerns the laws repealed by delegated legislation and the question of their revival if that legislation is later disallowed. The later disallowance does not lead to automatic revival of the laws repealed. This can result in an unfortunate situation in which there is a gap in the law where one ought not exist. This problem is particularly acute in relation to certain Australian Capital Territory laws.

A fifth flaw concerns the ability of those who make delegated legislation to do so in a way which infringes the Committee's principles, followed a short time later by its repeal and then its remaking in a similar form. Were this to happen the Senate, under the present rules, would be denied the opportunity to render ineffective the objectionable provisions. The thrust of the legislation repealed can be remade in a form retaining that thrust.

I know that the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has already begun to examine some of these questions and I urge him and the Senate to look closely at chapter 2 of the Committee's report. In conclusion, I would like to pay the following tributes. I will be brief about this. Firstly, Senator Missen was a past Chairman of the Committee and Chairman of the Commonwealth Delegated Legislation Committee. As Chairman, he carried on and strengthened a tradition of diligence and fearlessness in protecting rights when dealing with Ministers and the bureaucracy. Hopefully we carry on our work in that tradition. Secondly, the Committee would not be as effective as it is without the contribution made to its work by Senator Lewis, the Deputy Chairman, who, when himself Chairman, was undeterred by ministerial might if he thought rights and liberties were placed in jeopardy by delegated legislation. Thirdly, the Committee owes a great debt to its legal adviser, Professor Douglas Whalan of the Australian National University. Without his expert weekly legal reports we would have a much more difficult time in coming to grips with close to 1,000 instruments of delegated legislation per year. Finally, the Committee thanks its small staff. I mention in particular its outstanding Secretary, Peter O'Keefe; and Margaret Murphy, John Carter, Jan Wood and Helen Reid.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AMENDMENT (RECIPROCITY WITH ITALY) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Gareth Evans) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The main purpose of this Bill is to provide for the implementation of the reciprocal agreement on social security signed with Italy on 23 April this year. The Bill will also effect minor amendments to the Social Security Act 1947 to ensure that the agreement meshes with the Act.

The reciprocal agreement which has been concluded with Italy is the first in a network of new cost-sharing agreements which the Government is seeking to conclude with each of Australia's migrant source countries.

The background to this initiative was outlined in the statement of the Minister for Social Security to the House of Representatives on reciprocal social security agreements on 8 May 1985. A copy of that statement has been distributed to honourable senators with this speech.

Reciprocal social security agreements are formal arrangements which countries enter into to ensure that people who move between them receive social security pensions and benefits on a fair and equitable basis. They are treaties binding countries under international law and are put into effect under the domestic law of the countries concerned.
Like the agreement with Italy, Australia's future agreements will be based on principles which are in line with international practice. Those principles are:
Shared responsibility. Each party to the Agreement will contribute to a person's total social security coverage.
Equality of treatment. The residents and citizens of both countries will be given equal access to each other's social security laws.

Totalisation. Periods of residence and/or contributions in both countries will be added together to give people the minimum period of residence or contributions required to qualify for a pension from either or both countries.

Pro-rata basis. The total amount of pension to be paid by each country to people residing in the other will be based either on the length of a person's residence or contributions. (The Social Security Proportional Portability of Pensions Act 1986 enabled this principle to be adopted for Australia.)
The reciprocal agreement between Australia and Italy specifically addresses the social security rights of the following groups of people:
Those who have resided in Australia and cannot claim Australian pension entitlement because they now reside in Italy;
Those who ceased contributions to the Italian social security scheme when they migrated to Australia and who now cannot claim Italian pension entitlement; and
Those from Italy who are now in Australia and do not have access to Australian pensions because they have not resided here long enough.
The Government will be pressing to get the agreement with Italy ratified as soon as possible in order that the benefits it gives can flow to the intended beneficiaries.
In developing the agreement with Italy, the Government has formulated a four stage process to be followed for future agreements. This process involves:
Detailed exchanges of information, including written material and face-to-face meetings, to enable both country's officials to understand each other's social security systems;
Consultations with communities in Australia likely to be affected by an agreement;
Negotiation of the terms of an agreement, taking into account community views; and
Ratification, legislation and implementation.

In keeping with the undertaking of the Minister for Social Security to the ethnic communities in Australia, relevant communities will be consulted before the commencement of formal negotiations. Exchanges of information between Australia and the country in question need to take place before consultations can be conducted with the community concerned so that the implications and the viability of an agreement can be explored with the community and its concerns taken into account prior to the commencement of formal negotiations.
As with the community consultations in 1985, the Federation of Ethnic Communities' Councils of Australia will be invited to assist with further consultations.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Much has been made of the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill in regard to our obligations under the Convention in Trade in Endangered Species. It is worth while noting some of the responsibilities of the convention which are spelt out in Article VI. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: An export permit shall contain the information specified in the model set forth in Appendix IV and may only be used for export within a period of six months from the date it was granted.
It goes on to say:
A separate permit or certificate shall be required for each consignment of specimens.

But in this Bill we find that the amendments will now allow for multiple export permits lasting a full year, which is clearly not in the spirit of the convention. Also, it does not provide for gazettal of intention to export or for rights of review by the tribunal of 12 month export permits. This is against the intention of the Convention in Trade in Endangered Species. The amendments will allow any designated authority to send as many animals overseas as it wishes without fear of public accountability.

Evidence before the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare has shown that 90 per cent of exports go out unchecked, that fur and fauna identification squads have been disbanded and that container ships are rarely if ever searched. Federal and State police who are supposed to enforce the Wildlife Protection Act have no training whatever in identification. It is abundantly obvious that the kangaroo skin trade is unregulated. In what way will these amendments prevent these abuses? Of course they will not prevent these abuses. Is the Bill designed to ensure that the only bar between the free trade of our fauna and flora is a paper control of such lightweight nature that it virtually serves no control at all?

Proposed section 76A, clause 33, allows the designated authority, the Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, to delegate his or her powers upon ministerial approval to any officer or employee of the service. Presumably this could result in decisions to export being made by persons who are neither sufficiently qualified nor informed properly to assess whether an export is in the best interests of the animal or human communities. Does this mean that the cleaning woman at the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service can make the decision? I have a fear of bureaucracies. I fear giving them too much discretion. This flows probably from my own common sense and also from my viewing of the television program Yes Minister. I feel that it is a very dangerous precedent to allow the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service to delegate its powers in an undefined manner.

Clause 19 proposes to amend section 52 with the result that applications for permits need no longer be gazetted. Eliminating this requirement undermines the democratic principals by denying the public any meaningful participation in permit decisions. How is the public to know that the permits are even coming up? The public must be alerted to the present drive to violate the entire Australian environment. In the daily Press we find a number of articles showing that the New Right, the H. R. Nicholls Society-the hypocritical rip-off Nicholls Society-is now turning its attention to gaining open slather on all the protected lands in Australia. Some 15 mines are planned for stage 3 of Kakadu National Park. In today's Hobart Mercury newspaper we find the General Manager of Utah Development Co. Ltd criticising conservationists, whom he called preservationists. The article reads:

Developers and conservationists could work side by side but a dangerous element was trying to ``rap parts of the environment in a time cocoon'', the chairman of the environmental committee of the Australian Mining Industry Council, Mr Gavin McDonald, warned yesterday.

Is there anything really wrong with that? Why should we not preserve some part of our environment? The timber industry is also gearing up. It has a $1.75m campaign to say basically that logging is good for the environment. This assertion has been taken to task by the Acting Director of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation Institute of Biological Resources and Chief of the Division of Forest Research, Dr Joe Landsberg. He said:
. . . We still lack sufficient knowledge of the ecology of the forests and how they respond to logging, to say confidently that Australia's forests, as currently harvested, are a renewable resource.

The fact remains that the New Right has its sights set firmly on the protected lands of Australia. There is really nothing wrong with preserving patches of the environment for future generations. In fact, it is a laudable thing and we should be able to do this in our enlightenment in the late twentieth century. The United States National Parks Service has a charter which specifically states:

The service thus established shall promote and regulate the use of the federal areas known as national parks, monuments and reservations herein after specified by such means and measures as conform to the fundamental purpose of said parks, monuments and reservations, which purpose is to conserve the scenery and the natural and historic objects and the wildlife therein and to provide for the enjoyment of the same in such manner and by such means as will leave them unimpaired for the enjoyment of future generations.

It is a very beneficial time capsule. The Americans actually took their parks so seriously that when Yellowstone Park was declared and run by a manager for a number of years it came to the attention of the United States Congress that hunters, loggers were defiling the park. This caused the United States Congress to call in the cavalry. The cavalry actually patrolled Yellowstone Park for some 30 years with sabres and rifles to make sure that Yellowstone National Park was not exploited. It would be wonderful if the Federal and State governments shared this attitude towards the preservation of our natural environment, but of course they do not. The attitude really is one of residuals. When an area is no longer of any economic use to the mining companies, the loggers, the hydroelectric commissions or the dam builders it is declared a national park. We obviously have the cart before the horse. This is the residuals approach and it has no place in our modern society.

What should we be doing? I think we should go back to basic philosophy. We should go back to our own philosophy of Australia, and determine whether we have any idea of what we have in Australia. I believe that we do not. While we may love our country, we certainly do not respect our land. We have to develop a philosophy of protection of the land. The Japanese, perhaps, hold some hope. A Zen scholar, Sojo, in the fifth century wrote:
Heaven and earth and I are of the same root, the ten thousand things and I are of one substance.

I wish the Japanese would take a good look at this when they oversee their wood chipping plans for Australia. In our culture we have a Judaeo-Christian ethic. This has often been used by the developers as an excuse for exploitation of the environment. They say that the Bible says: `Go forth, multiply and subdue the earth'.

TALK.START.PARA: —`Go forth, be plentiful and replenish the earth', is the quote.

—This is one interpretation. I have seen it written elsewhere. At any rate, I have heard the developers say that they have a biblical right, an injunction, to use the environment in any way that they see fit and that we, as conservationists, should not interfere with their activities. Therefore, I would respectfully propose an eleventh commandment for the Judaeo-Christians in our society. It would encompass the knowledge of the Aboriginal people, and the American Indians, and even some Zen Buddhism. My eleventh commandment would read: Respect the earth and the creatures and the plants upon it, so that thy days and thy children's days will be long and fruitful.
—That is very touching.

—Senator Evans says that it is touching. I think it is a necessity in this day and age. We are not in contact with our environment and we should be, because, after all, it is the environment which sustains us.
—Much more defensible than the prohibition--

—I hope it is defensible. I hope the Minister embraces it with all of his considerable intellect, wit and charm. At a time when our native flora and fauna are under ever increasing threat, we must take strong legislative steps to close the loopholes in existing laws. Instead of closing the gaps, this Bill uses a bulldozer to create even bigger opportunities for those wishing to overexploit our native species and their habitat. This Bill must be sent to the animal welfare Committee in order to address the massive problems facing our wildlife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard Senator Sanders give a long dissertation on the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill 1986. I would like to make a couple of comments on his contribution to the debate. I do not support his amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Bill, proposing that the Bill be sent to the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare for report. I think that the Select Committee on Animal Welfare has quite enough on its plate without taking on a lot of extra work. It would most probably take it into a lot of different areas that I think would be better looked at by other persons. I do not think a lot would be achieved in the short term by the Committee taking it on.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sanders referred to an article in the Sydney Morning Herald that reported a supposed illegal skin trade. I do not think that Senator Sanders should believe everything that he reads in newspapers, because sometimes they are not always absolutely correct. He is probably as well aware as I am that those allegations have come from one group that appeared before the Senate Committee and that other groups dispute those figures. At this stage I think neither side has been proved right and it is rather premature, if not inappropriate, to use such selective allegations. The Committee is still taking evidence on the subject. If we as a committee had all the answers and knew all the facts, as Senator Sanders implies, we would not have the need to continue taking evidence. I certainly have not made up my mind on the subject, and I hope that Senator Sanders has an open mind on the matter.

The Bill is basically tidying up several administrative problems that became evident with the existing legislation. As previous speakers have said, the Bill allows us to meet international obligations for the protection and conservation of the world's wildlife. Perhaps more importantly, the Bill outlines controls for the export of Australian plants and animals and the import of live animals. It will simplify some unnecessary administrative procedures, clarify and tighten penalties and provide increased protection for those who provide information on people involved in animal or bird smuggling operations.

Australia is a very rich country in the variety and wealth of beautiful, and in many cases unique, fauna and flora. For that reason, it is also a target for bird and animal dealers from overseas who have developed some extremely sophisticated networks to export illegally birds and animals for sale to clients overseas. To those living in Australia, especially farmers in many areas of Australia, the idea of someone paying $500 or $1,000 or even more for something as common as a galah or a sulphur-crested cockatoo is probably unbelievable. Yet a very lucrative illegal trade is being carried on in those two species and indeed in other less common but nevertheless plentiful varieties. Galahs and cockatoos are some of the biggest pests to farmers that this country has produced. Each year farmers develop a variety of methods to keep these birds away from their crops. As a farmer, I can assure the Senate that there is nothing quite so frustrating when sowing a crop as finding a hundred or a thousand birds behind the tractor grabbing the seed as it leaves the combine and falls into the seed bed. It is equally frustrating to see a crop that is ready for harvest decimated in minutes by the same birds. As I think has been mentioned here before in this debate, with sunflower crops particularly the economic loss is quite considerable.

Yet the commercial export of birds such as the galahs and the cockatoos is forbidden. I am aware of the many arguments put forward to support this ban, but I cannot but wonder whether it is on only animal welfare grounds that we are doing the right thing. The number of smugglers caught by Customs each year and the number of dead birds found can be only a very small percentage of the total trade. Frankly, the thought of travelling overseas and sitting in a plane for several hours with a number of birds or, as one man from Darwin had, a number of live pythons strapped to me or in my luggage does not really appeal to me. That would probably give one, and some of the passengers sitting near one, if they knew about it, a bit of a squirmy feeling.

The lucrative nature of the trade probably makes the risk and the discomfort worth while, although I doubt that the birds or the snakes so smuggled would think so. On animal welfare grounds alone, one would want to try to stop a trade which shoves birds and animals in airless little compartments and one in which they probably have a less than 50 per cent live delivery rate. A number of criticisms have been made to me over the control and regulations of wildlife exports. Much of the criticism has come from people involved in the flora and fauna trade. They are critical of many aspects of both import and export, and considerable concern has been expressed about the penalties meted out and the inconsistent and selective nature of the prosecutions. We must remember that we are not dealing with some backyard, petty operation catering for some fanatic who wants his own exotic birds or animals or whatever. In Australia we are dealing with a multimillion dollar business. Figures such as $40m a year have been cited.

Of even more concern is the fact that there is considerable evidence to link the wildlife smuggling trade with the drug trade. It has been suggested that a plane load of exotic birds travelling from Australia to, say, Bangkok can be swapped for a return load of heroin. It is therefore a serious problem and one to which too little attention had been paid to date. In fact, there have been only five cases of wildlife smuggling brought to court since the existing Act came into force in 1984. That indicates, I believe, both the difficulty of the problem and the attitude to wildlife smuggling.
