QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 5 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Government support recommendation number 12 of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking which suggests that the Australian Federal Police should develop itself as a detective investigational force, endeavouring to specialise in areas which are difficult for State Police forces.
(2) Why does the Government support or not support the above recommendation.
(3) Does the Government share Mr Justice Stewart's belief that the Australian Federal Police should provide assistance, not competition, to the State Police forces.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The Government supports the development of the Australian Federal Police (AFP) as an effective federal investigative body, functioning as the Commonwealth's primary law enforcement agency. This approach formed the basis of the statement tabled in Parliament on 10 September 1985, which sets out the objectives and priorities of the AFP.
(2) The long term role for the AFP is consistent with its top priorities, which are: investigations into drug trafficking, organised crime, and large scale fraud against Commonwealth revenue.

(3) Yes. The AFP works in close co-operation with State Police Forces in a variety of ways including Joint Task Forces, joint co-operative investigations, intelligence sharing, and full participation in bodies such as the National Crime Authority and the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 5 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: What action has been taken to improve co-operation between Federal and State Police forces and to ensure that the Australian Federal Police pass on all their intelligence material to the respective State bodies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Most Australian Federal Police (AFP) intelligence, with the exception of telephone intercept material and that relating to sensitive, current investigations, is shared via computer with the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence (ABCI). This data base is, in turn, acces- sible by all State Bureaux of Criminal Intelligence and the National Crime Authority.

In regard to telephone interception material, legislation precludes the sharing of acquired information unless it relates to what could be generally termed ``serious crime''. In such cases, the information is passed on under terms specified by the legislation to the appropriate police commissioner.

All State Bureaux of Criminal Intelligence have direct computer access to the AFP's Master Names Index. Intelligence relating to current, sensitive investigations is restricted, even within the AFP, on a ``need to know'' basis.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 5 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Are the recruitment and training policies of the Australian Federal Police kept under review, in view of the Government's response to recommendations 37 and 39 of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking; if so, what methods are employed for this purpose, and how frequently are they reviewed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 5 June 1986:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Monitoring of Persons Released on Bail

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 5 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What further consideration has been given by the Government to recommendations 79 and 80 of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking dealing with systems for the monitoring of persons released on bail.
(2) Has the A.C.T. incorporated provisions along the lines of those recommended by Mr Justice Stewart into its bail legislation; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney- General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Commonwealth supports action for review of these procedures. The New South Wales Government has advised that the upgrading of police computer facilities will enable closer supervision of persons released on bail in that State. All Commonwealth prosecution bodies have been directed to keep records to facilitate the proper monitoring of the operation of bail legislation.
(2) Special bail legislation for the A.C.T. is in the course of preparation. The recommendations of Mr Justice Stewart are being taken into account in the preparation of that legislation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 5 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What further consideration has the Government given to recommendation 92 of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking concerning the use of tape and/or video recording at the scene of a drug raid.
(2) Will the above matter be discussed during the Government's proposed review of the Criminal Investigation Bill.

(3) Has the Government made efforts to implement fully recommendations 89 and 91 of Mr Justice Stewart's Report which propose greatly increased use of forensic chemists both at the scene of a drug seizure and for re-weighing and re-analysing narcotics prior to destruction.
(4) Have additional forensic staff been appointed in response to the above proposals.

(5) Have measures been taken by the Government to implement recommendation 90 of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking concerning destruction of most of a quantity of a seized narcotics shortly after seizure.
(6) Has the above matter been raised at the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General for further discussion.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) I am advised by the Attorney-General that Recommendation 92 of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking is to be considered in the course of the review of the Criminal Investigation Bill 1981.

(3) Recommendation 89 of Mr Justice Stewart's Report has been implemented by alternative arrangements. It is not practical that seized narcotics be re-analysed and re-weighed prior to destruction unless the destruction occurs immediately after re-analysis and re-weighing. To ensure continuity and the security intended by this recommendation, the Australian Federal Police, however, now employs measures calculated to provide a secure, accountable and practicable method of safeguarding narcotic seizures against theft or interference.

Recommendation 91 of Mr Justice Stewart's Report is not to be implemented by the Government as it is not practicable that forensic chemists should have custody of drugs from the time of seizure to the time of destruction. Alternative arrangements have been made which allow for both the security of seizures and for investigative requirements, and these have been embodied in AFP General Orders and Instructions.

(5) Recommendation 90 of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking was considered at the Australian Police Ministers' Council on 16 May 1986. Council resolved that the pre-trial destruction of drugs is a matter for individual jurisdictions to address. In the federal sphere, following receipt of advice from the Director of Public Prosecutions and the Australian Government Solicitor, the Australian Federal Police policy on the destruction of drugs was promulgated and is contained in an amendment to AFP General Order No. 24. The amendment sets out the specific conditions which are to govern the destruction of seized narcotics including authorisation procedures and evidentiary requirements. Arrangements within the AFP for the audit of drug destruction systems provide an additional safeguard.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 16 September 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Australian Government accept and agree with President Reagan's interpretation of the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty; if so, does the Australian Government agree with United States proposals to extensively research, develop and test new ABM systems, especially the SDI program; if not, has the Australian Government made its views known to the United States Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government takes the view that mutual confidence in the continued integrity of the ABM Treaty is of great importance to the prospects of an agreement between the superpowers to radically reduce their nuclear arsenals. As the honourable Senator is aware the Government does not endorse the SDI or what it accepts to be a comparable program of research in the Soviet Union. Although the Government is not opposed to research into strategic defences as such it is seriously concerned that the present research programs will undermine confidence in the integrity of the ABM Treaty and thus seriously compound the difficulty of reaching agreement to reduce the offensive nuclear forces. In the absence of access to the full negotiating record the Government cannot make an independent judgment on the broader interpretation of what is permitted under the ABM Treaty, which the Reagan Administration accepted as valid in October 1985. However, the Government attaches importance to the fact that President Reagan has formally indicated that the SDI research program will be conducted in accordance with the traditional restrictive interpretation of the obligations under the ABM Treaty. The Government's views and concerns in respect of these matters have been clearly conveyed to the United States Government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 27 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Department of Resources and Energy maintain records of nuclear accidents and reports about them; if so, on how many occasions does it believe that accidents have occurred without a prompt public announcement being made.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:
